comments:
OK, I won't notify you again about this release, but will get in touch when a new version is available. If you'd rather skip all updates until the next major or minor version, let me know by commenting `@dependabot ignore this major version` or `@dependabot ignore this minor version`. You can also ignore all major, minor, or patch releases for a dependency by adding an [`ignore` condition](https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/configuration-options-for-dependency-updates#ignore) with the desired `update_types` to your config file.

If you change your mind, just re-open this PR and I'll resolve any conflicts on it.
This dependency will be updated at a later point in time when I have finalized the ESM conversion for the tests.

body: very minor, but corrected to the official spelling.
commit_messages: Fix Typescript to TypeScript on plugin page (#8961)

comments:
Since this is an extension on the Leaflet repository being replaced I don't think we want to merge this. While I acknowledge that currently our maintenance of plugins under our banner is not where it needs to be I think this is jumping the gun.

Closing this PR.
Is there a plan to improve the situation? People have to deal with issues in the "official plugins" that have been fixed in some forks for a long time.
Submit a PR to fix those issues, we'll get to it when we can. Currently our main priorities are to work on Leaflet 2.0, the plugins will come later.
Okay, this prioritization is understandable. Thank you for your work! 🙂

body:
Replaces [expect.js](https://github.com/Automattic/expect.js/) with [Chai](https://www.chaijs.com/) for assertions in our tests. Expect is unmaintained (last commit 9 years ago and no issue activity), and does not have an ESM variant.

We'll likely be moving from Karma to Web Test Runner, which comes with [Chai by default](https://modern-web.dev/docs/test-runner/writing-tests/helper-libraries/#assertions). This moves to closing #8939.
comments: Nice! A little puzzled by all the test failures though, what's up with that?
Yeah, gotta figure that out. Looks to be something specific to Firefox and Safari as Chrome works fine.
Looks like I missed a couple of tests specific to touch interaction that I forgot to run locally. Should be all good now.
commit_messages: Replace expect.js with Chai (#8952)

body:
Bumps [engine.io](https://github.com/socketio/engine.io) from 6.4.1 to 6.4.2.
Release notes

Sourced from engine.io's releases.

6.4.2

:warning: This release contains an important security fix :warning:

A malicious client could send a specially crafted HTTP request, triggering an uncaught exception and killing the Node.js process:

TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'handlesUpgrades')
  at Server.onWebSocket (build/server.js:515:67)

Please upgrade as soon as possible.

Bug Fixes

  • include error handling for Express middlewares (#674) (9395782)
  • prevent crash when provided with an invalid query param (fc480b4)
  • typings: make clientsCount public (#675) (bd6d471)
  • uws: prevent crash when using with middlewares (8b22162)

Credits

Huge thanks to @​tyilo and @​cieldeville for helping!

Links

body: Changes the unit tests so they use the named exports from Leaflet loaded trough an import map.
comments: Interesting, tests sometimes fail. I have no idea why yet, will look at it another time (gotta sleep).

> Interesting, tests sometimes fail. I have no idea why yet, will look at it another time (gotta sleep).

Looks like all the failures are timeouts — I guess browsers take to long to hop through all the imports and fetch everything.

Also noting that the total test time jumps from <3m to 6–8m. We should look into addressing that before shipping — perhaps this alone would be enough to keep running against the bundle. It may also be beneficial because some issues may only manifest after bundling, which is how users end up using the code anyway, so tests closer to real world.

> Perhaps this alone would be enough to keep running against the bundle.

How do you mean? We are currently still running the tests against the bundled code. Or are you referring to #8937?

I am not quite sure what is causing the performance to regress so much, I'll have to take a look and investigate deeper.
@jonkoops ah right, I missed that it's not yet implementing individual file import. But the regression is indeed suspicious — let's make sure it's not slower before we can land this.
I'm closing this PR so that I can merge this work into a larger effort to start using [Web Test Runner](https://modern-web.dev/docs/test-runner/overview/). See #8939 for more information.

body:
This PR refactors the Karma configuration so that the Rollup pre-proccesor is no longer included. This is needed for a subsequent that is in the works that converts the tests to load Leaflet using import maps (and fully ESM).

This PR also:
- Removes the `spec/index.html` file in favor of using Karma's server.
- Runs Karma in watch mode by default so tests are ran when changes are made to the tests or source.
- Adds a type annotation so that IDEs can provide documentation and auto completion of the Karma config.
- Aligns the values of the Karma config as much as possible with the defaults.
comments: @Falke-Design I expect this to change when we move from Karma to Web Test Runner. The debugging experience there should be a lot more integrated and intuitive.
commit_messages: Remove Rollup pre-proccesor from Karma runner (#8935)

body: Adds Leaflet to an [import map](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/script/type/importmap) for each of the examples in the `debug` directory. This allows Leaflet to be imported using `import {} from 'leaflet'`.
comments:
@jonkoops maybe worth condensing the import map a little so that the pages don't look as verbose? E.g.:

```html
<script type="importmap">{"imports": {"leaflet": "../../dist/leaflet-src.esm.js"}}</script>
```

Yeah, I was also thinking of ways to reduce the boilerplate for the debug pages. I think it's probably fine for now since folks will copy and paste the contents of these files. But perhaps a better solution would be to have some kind of re-usable template for the outer HTML of these pages.

Personally, I'd rather have the importmaps be more readable, at least by now. Users should be able to see how the importmap is looking like instead of copy-pasting the magic one-liner. It's worth the 20 or so extra bytes.
More exiting ESM and import map stuff on the way, working on the tests now :eyes:
commit_messages: Use import maps to load Leaflet in the `debug` directory (#8926)

body: Since I've refactored all the examples for ESM support I have also taken some time to ensure the pass the linter in the same manner as other code. This means we can now remove the ignored directory from our linting config.
commit_messages: Lint files in `debug` directory (#8925)

body: Converts the vector debug pages (located in `debug/vector`) to ESM and cleans up the code in the process. This is part of a greater effort to land ESM as a first-class citizen. Code that was broken has been replaced with working code or removed.
comments: Went ahead and fixed the review comments as well, I'll merge this in :+1: Thanks again @Falke-Design!
commit_messages: Convert vector debug pages to ESM (#8924)

body: Converts the test debug pages (located in `debug/tests`) to ESM and cleans up the code in the process. This is part of a greater effort to land ESM as a first-class citizen. Code that was broken has been replaced with working code or removed.
comments:
How are you planning on loading the module on browsers?

I've been starting to use `importmap`s recently, and they feel fantastic. Do have a look at https://gitlab.com/IvanSanchez/leaflet.gleo/-/blob/main/demo/sprites.html#L7

Funny you mention Import Maps @IvanSanchez, because that is exactly how I was planning on distributing Leaflet 2.0! For folks that do not want to use a package manager or bundlers I think it's the best way we can ship Leaflet.

Reason why I haven't been using them yet is because up until the latest version of Safari (just released) it was not possible to use them there. I have every intention of converting all these examples to Import Maps before we ship 2.0.

@Falke-Design Yes, I'd like to start thinking about documentation. I think we need to put in a little work to ensure we're not deploying it from `main` anymore. Or perhaps we need a `v2.leaflet.com` for the new docs.
commit_messages: Convert test debug pages to ESM (#8921)

body:
Changes the implementation of `preventOutline()` and `restoreOutline()` so that [`outline-style`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/outline-style) is set rather than the whole [`outline`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/outline) property. This seems to prevent a regression introduced in Safari 16.4, and remains functional in other browsers.

Closes #8908
comments: Yes, I tested this manually in the latest versions of Chrome, Firefox and Safari. They all seem to have the expected behavior.
commit_messages: Set `outlineStyle` instead of `outline` when preventing outline (#8917)

body:
fixes #8778

![control-layers-adding-layer-mobile](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19800037/230868836-188dda42-10ef-4172-a075-a123c1cc5a01.gif)

### Cherry-pick into `v1`
comments: @jonkoops @mourner @IvanSanchez please review, I would like to release a new `1.9` version soon.

Hi @Falke-Design 

Oh, I can confirm the fix with L.control.layers! 

The problem was that I was testing in a app where I'm using Leaflet.Control.Layers.Tree (https://github.com/jjimenezshaw/Leaflet.Control.Layers.Tree). In this case, it keeps with the same behaviour:

https://plnkr.co/edit/W135NFAEtQV0a3ZK

https://run.plnkr.co/plunks/W135NFAEtQV0a3ZK

Do you think it needs to be fixed also in Leaflet.Control.Layers.Tree?

> Hi @Falke-Design
> 
> Oh, I can confirm the fix with L.control.layers!
> 
> The problem was that I was testing in a app where I'm using Leaflet.Control.Layers.Tree (https://github.com/jjimenezshaw/Leaflet.Control.Layers.Tree). In this case, it keeps with the same behaviour:
> 
> https://plnkr.co/edit/W135NFAEtQV0a3ZK
> 
> https://run.plnkr.co/plunks/W135NFAEtQV0a3ZK
> 
> Do you think it needs to be fixed also in Leaflet.Control.Layers.Tree?

Hi @Falke-Design 
After update to 1.9.4, I can confirm that the fix works great with L.control.layers, but not with Leaflet.Control.Layers.Tree. 
Do you think it needs to be fixed in the Leaflet.Control.Layers.Tree side?
Thanks!
@PedroVenancio yeah I'm pretty sure that this needs to be added in `Leaflet.Control.Layers.Tree` too. Make an issue on their repo please.
commit_messages: Prevent adding layer while expanding Layer-Control on mobile (#8910)

body: First, thank you to everyone that maintains Leaflet! This PR aims to adopt the "Proposed solution" in #7529 to provide missing contextual information. More specifically, when the `collapsed` option is set to `false`, this PR adds an `aria-label` with a value of `Layers` to the `leaflet-control-layers-list` element. Please let me know if this looks okay, and if not, I'm happy to make changes.
comments:
PR solve the issue, thank you 👍 

But I'm not sure if the aria-label should also be added when it is expanded after being collapsed. Because `<a class="leaflet-control-layers-toggle">` will be set to `display: none` too.
![aria-label-control-layers](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19800037/230841764-f397f109-7ef3-4aa6-893d-add101c2340c.gif)

@Malvoz can you please help
Thank you for looking at this! That is an excellent point about the case where it is expanded after being collapsed. Please let me know if you want me to add this part.

Thank you @jonkoops and @Falke-Design! My apologies for not being able to fix this until now - I've added some more commits that (1) resolve the merge conflict, and (2) add some tests for the ```aria-label``` to make sure it is working as expected. Please let me know if this looks okay or if I should make changes, and many thanks again.

body:
Fix #8905, `mix-blend-mode` issue with custom svg-tiles. The bug was introduced in #8891.

Needs to be cherry-picked into `v1`
comments: Other than my nitpicking on the CSS formatting, looks good to me. I'd like @joeberkovitz to have a look and see if #8905 is fixed satisfactorily.
I have retested this and #8905 appears to be fixed by this PR, while still addressing the original concern of gaps between tiles.
Nice, thanks for fixing this @Falke-Design

body:
Optimizes the panInside method for better performance. The changes simplify the code and reduce the number of calculations needed to determine whether the map needs to be panned.

The main changes are:

- Use destructuring to simplify the code for **options**.
- Use the || operator to set default values for **paddingTL** and **paddingBR**.
- Use **let** instead of **const** for **pixelCenter** and **pixelPoint**, since they will be modified later.
- Use **let** instead of **const** for **paddedBounds** and **paddedSize**, since they may be modified later.
- Combine the **centerOffset** and **offset** calculations into a single step, and use **Math.sign** to simplify the conditional statements for adjusting the **pixelCenter**.

These changes should improve the performance of the **panInside** method, especially when it is called frequently or with large padding values.
comments: I'm gonna veto this, on the gut feeling that the text of the PR seems right out of chatGPT.

body:
This alleviates the dreaded tile gaps of #3575, in a clean way, with no downsides that I'm aware of.

The tile gaps are still visible if the page zoom is not 100%, however (see https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/3575#issuecomment-1485077575).

Credit goes to @lapo-luchini (see https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/3575#issuecomment-1484816250).
comments: I cherry-picked this CSS change to apply for a project that uses Leaflet 1.8 and it created problems with the colors of overlying markers. I don't know if anyone's tested this in combination with markers based on SVG file-based icons but it might be a good idea to verify that it doesn't break them.

@joeberkovitz Could you please [open a bug report](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/new/choose) with that info? I haven't done throughout testing, but if you can provide a minimal test case where colours of overlaying markers are affected, that'd be very useful.

@IvanSanchez I've opened bug https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/8905 which demonstrates the issue. It turns out to need a more refined test case than just straight-up markers, it requires a custom GridLayer displaying vector point data using SVG icons from adjacent tiles where the icons (not the tiles) overlap. I've explained why I think this is a valid use case in the bug.

This does not seem to work in Firefox, and also has the side effect of making the "overlap" [fix](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/3575#issuecomment-150544739) from #3575 fail, since the overlapped border is lightened.
@mhirsch please report this as a new issue with some steps to reproduce it.

Please note **this CSS property has a performance cost** associated with it.

Our client uses virtualised desktops that don't have access to a GPU and we lost 10-20 FPS when we upgraded to Leaflet 1.9.4. Took me a while to trace it back to this, but fortunately it's easy to override the style and turn this off. We've never noticed the issue it's supposed to address.

You should be able to see it for yourself. Just turn off hardware acceleration in your browser settings, show the dev tools FPS meter, and pan a map around. Toggle the CSS property between `plus-lighter` and `normal` and you should see a difference in FPS.

Some downsides of this approach can be mitigated with exceptions in CSS #9560.

I can confirm a drop of around 50% FPS (120→60) without GPU acceleration. To my knowledge there is no reliable way to detect if hardware acceleration is enabled. Maybe you should add a setting to control how tile gaps are handled (plus-lighter, overlap or nothing), but ideally the control should be left to the user.

body:
My use-case is this: I'm using latest Leaflet (1.9.3) alongside with [Leaflet.VectorGrid](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet.VectorGrid/) (which is a bit outdated but anyway).

When I set up a VectorGrid layer, set `interactive: true` to its options, and add `myVectorGridLayer.on('click', ...)` event handling (also works with mousedown, per se), I have an error that says "latlng is not defined". This is probably caused by VectorGrid not using latlng by default, so I patched VectorGrid, but in the end I realized that "mouseover" also causes this "latlng is not defined" error right in the Canvas renderer.

So here is this patch.

I don't know Leaflet internals enough to see if this fix is the right one or if I should fix something upstream, so feel free to reject, but please send explanations if you do, so that we can learn more about internals 🙏
comments:
Ok, so I see there's https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet.VectorGrid/pull/281 related to this.

But... what's the problem this is trying to solve? Under what condition does a pointer event not have `latlng`?

> But... what's the problem this is trying to solve? Under what condition does a pointer event not have `latlng`?

I have no idea, I guess it's caused by VectorGrid, but could not find the origin. Spent a whole week on this without finding out. But as said, I lack knowledge about internals of both libs, and that's my "current workaround" 😕
Looking at the code changes I don't understand in which case this would be occurring in Leaflet. Seems like the issue is stemming from the plugin itself?

> Looking at the code changes I don't understand in which case this would be occurring in Leaflet. Seems like the issue is stemming from the plugin itself?

Yeah, VectorGrid does very ugly things with the `L.Path` code and the hijacking of the `L.Renderer`s into tiles. I'm not surprised there's bugs in there.

But I'm curious as to what the conditions to reproduce the bug are. It's fine if it's only reproducible in VectorGrid.... but last time I checked, pointer events in VectorGrid worked just fine for the common use cases.

> But I'm curious as to what the conditions to reproduce the bug are.

Yeah me too. @Pierstoval any chance you could add a test that reproduces this issue?

It's really hard for me to make a reproducer as it's part of an internal (quite big) library I'm working on for my client, and also hard since we're using GeoServer as data source, Svelte as framework, and Typescript as JS flavour, that's a lot to extract from private code 😭 

However, I could show it in a private not-recorded video call, that would be fine 👌

I'm sorry, but we are quite swamped at the moment so video calling is not an option (at least for me). If there is no minimal reproducible example for this issue I don't feel like we can confidently merge this in.

I am going to close this PR for that reason. There is just to much uncertainty around this implementation.

If you do manage to reproduce this issue purely with Leaflet itself, feel free to report an issue with a reproducible example.

I spent the whole week trying to find other solutions, and in the end we made a compromise of using a pure GeoJSON layer that queries GeoServer on every map zoom/pan. Not perfect in terms of performance, but at least it contains everything we need. And we combined it with a more common WMS layer for zoom levels containing a lot of elements.

For the people who come here, Leaflet isn't the problem. The VectorGrid plugin is, in this case.

Thanks anyway for the review 👌

body:
Closes #8843 

- Adds checks to for-in loops to ensure they are not looping over inherited properties.
- Enables [lint rule](https://eslint.org/docs/latest/rules/guard-for-in) to ensure these guards are enabled in future code.
- Does NOT add a guard to `Util.extend` as this code purposely copies properties from source objects.
comments:
Thanks for the PR, this looks great!

> * Does NOT add a guard to `Util.extend` as this code purposely copies properties from source objects.

Just wondering, are there many instances of us relying on this behavior? This feels a bit awkward to do it now... Perhaps if there are just a few places like this, we could switch there to prototype inheritance via `Object.create`?

Thanks for taking a look! A few thoughts on the `Util.extend`:

- The main place where it seems like the inherited property copying is needed in this `extend` is when working with `LatLng`. I think this may be related to how `LatLng` does not inherit from Leaflet's `Class` object, but I'm not 100% sure. There may be some opportunity to easily move away from using `Util.extend` when dealing with `LatLng`, but it's something that would require a closer look. I'm happy to look into it, but due to my inexperience with the codebase I might need a bit of support.
- Even if we do move away from relying on `Util.extend` to copy inherited properties internally, I would be wary of changing the way the function works. As I understand it, it gets exported as `L.extend` and may be used extensively by other code that depends on Leaflet. Changing it to no longer copy inherited properties would likely break other projects in confusing ways.

Because dealing with these issues looks non-trivial, I would vote to not include them in this PR and instead open a separate issue to investigate them after this code is merged. What do you think @mourner ?

> Just wondering, are there many instances of us relying on this behavior? This feels a bit awkward to do it now... Perhaps if there are just a few places like this, we could switch there to prototype inheritance via `Object.create`?

I've ran into this when refactoring `Class` over to `Object.create()` in certain parts. I'd like to get rid of this as well, but perhaps we should log a separate issue for it.

> I think in a lot of cases here we can avoid calling Object.hasOwn() by looping over the result of Object.entries() instead (which should already check this for us).

I like the idea! The challenge here is that we can only use `Object.entries` if the object is not null or undefined. We could add additional null checks before each of the loops, but I think then things start to get more cluttered than just using the `hasOwn` guard.

I went through and identified some cases where I could confidently say that the object being iterated over is not null or undefined, and in those cases I switched to using `Object.entries` like you suggested. Let me know if you see other spots where we can be sure the object is non-null. Thanks!
Hi @jonkoops, is there still interest in this PR? Happy to either update this one or to take a stab at a version using only `Object.entries` and a bunch of null checks if that's preferred. Thanks!

Sorry for the recent negligence , I have been rather busy at work so I have had no time to get back to this PR.

We can always improve the code at a later point with `Object.entries()` where it makes sense. I think this is already a great improvement so I am going ahead and merge in this work.



Thanks for your contribution @alope107!

No worries @jonkoops, the review is much appreciated! If there are any other issues or tasks you'd recommend for someone starting to get their feet wet with this repo, feel free to let me know. It was fun starting to get to know the codebase!

Sure @alope107, if you are looking for new issues to pick up we do try to label those we think are good contributions with the ["help wanted"](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3A%22help+wanted%22) label. Feel free to take a look at any of those.
commit_messages: Guard for-in loops and enable guard-for-in lint rule. (#8879)

body:
Finally, my [not-so-secret project](https://gitlab.com/IvanSanchez/gleo) to have a WebGL map library with a leaflet-like API now has a Leaflet connector. Conceptually, this plugin is similar to the D3SvgOverlay and PixiOverlay, so I've put it in the same category.

I'm stupidly proud of the ["one thousand moving markers repeating across the antimeridian" demo](https://ivansanchez.gitlab.io/leaflet.gleo/demo/sprites.html).
comments: Very nice work @IvanSanchez!

Plugins: Add Leaflet.Gleo (#8877)

body:
Moves the initialization logic for sub-classes extending `Class` into the constructor of `Class` itself. This allows classes that extend using the `extends` keyword (rather than `Class.extend()`) to perform initialization logic as well.

Implements parts of #8806.
comments: If nobody has any objections I will go ahead and merge this in.
Thanks @Falke-Design
commit_messages: Move initialization logic for sub-classes to `Class` constructor (#8872)

body:
Converts `Class`  into an actual [JavaScript `class`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Classes). This PR does not attempt to refactor the existing implementation in any other way aside from moving the methods into the class definition itself.

I tried to keep the diff as reasonable as possible, but Github is showing a lot of white-space changes. I would recommend to check out the branch and inspect the diff in your IDE.

Implements parts of #8806.
comments: > Looks good +1 GitHub has a "hide whitespace" option in the UI: > > TIL, fancy.
commit_messages: Convert `Class` to a JavaScript `class` (#8871)

body:
Fixes #8859.

Judging from the table at https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/7403#issuecomment-1101669097 and https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/8859#issuecomment-1439989299 , something has changed between chrome  v100 and v109 (rather, from the underlying blink engine, since it applies to Edge too). 

v100 was doing a `deltaY` of `225`, whereas v109 now does `120`, so it's just enough to *un*cover the linux+chrome hack.

I'd like somebody else (with a linux box and chrome/chromium >=v109) to test that this in indeed the case.
comments:
@zdila, @paulatthehug last time you did some testing for us in #8298, would it possible for you to run this demo on your linux machine? https://plnkr.co/edit/eecQ7iqySIccbB0X

https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/8859#issuecomment-1439989299

As mentioned in this PR, after updating packages on my Debian testing ~2 weeks ago Leaflet now again scrolls 2 zoom levels on single wheel "click" in Vivaldi and Chrome. (In Firefox it works correctly.)

It is the same with this demo.

```
{
    "User-agent": "Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/110.0.0.0 Safari/537.36",
    "Leaflet": "1.9.3",
    "Win": false,
    "Gecko": false,
    "Chrome": true,
    "Edge": false,
    "Safari": false,
    "Retina": true,
    "wheelDeltaY": 225,
    "deltaMode": 0,
    "deltaY": -225,
    "deltaX": 0,
    "deltaZ": 0,
    "wheelDelta": 225,
    "detail": 0,
    "devicePixelRatio": 1.875,
    "Zoom delta": -2
}
```

@zdila Interesting, I'm getting a `deltaY` of `120` with a `devicePixelRatio` of `1`, and you're getting `225` with `1.875`. 

In the table with the data for chromium v100, we were getting a `deltaY` of `100`, and a (deprecated) `wheelDeltaY` of `225` with `devicePixelRatio` of `1.875`.

Now with zoomed-out test page to 30% (to change `devicePixelRatio`):

Vivaldi:

```
{
    "User-agent": "Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/110.0.0.0 Safari/537.36",
    "Leaflet": "1.9.3",
    "Win": false,
    "Gecko": false,
    "Chrome": true,
    "Edge": false,
    "Safari": false,
    "Retina": true,
    "wheelDeltaY": 225,
    "deltaMode": 0,
    "deltaY": -225,
    "deltaX": 0,
    "deltaZ": 0,
    "wheelDelta": 225,
    "detail": 0,
    "devicePixelRatio": 0.5625,
    "Zoom delta": -2
}
```

Chrome @ 33%:

```
{
    "User-agent": "Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/110.0.0.0 Safari/537.36",
    "Leaflet": "1.9.3",
    "Win": false,
    "Gecko": false,
    "Chrome": true,
    "Edge": false,
    "Safari": false,
    "Retina": false,
    "wheelDeltaY": 225,
    "deltaMode": 0,
    "deltaY": -225,
    "deltaX": 0,
    "deltaZ": 0,
    "wheelDelta": 225,
    "detail": 0,
    "devicePixelRatio": 0.625,
    "Zoom delta": -3
}
```

Gotcha: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1270089#c25

> Date: Wed Oct 26 22:43:59 2022
> 
> [linux] Fixed the mouse wheel scroll delta to match Windows.
> 
> Chromium historically used 53 pixels as delta for one wheel click when scrolling with the mouse wheel.  This is perceived as too few by many users (see the linked crbug).
> 
> This patch changes the value to 120, which makes Chromuim on Linux behaving the same way like it does on Windows, and making it very close to what Firefox does.

Seems like users are now complaining that chrome v109 "scrolls too fast", see https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1406625

If anybody has a google account (I don't), please leave a comment on that bug report, about this leaflet PR. The values in the `wheel` mouse event are correct as of now (v109/v110, i.e. "same as firefox"), regardless of the actual visible scroll distance.

I guess this goes back to the definition of the `deltaMode` of wheel events. Seems like chromium is assuming that's CSS pixels, but Firefox is assuming device pixels. I honestly don't have the will to complain to the W3C about this.

> Seems like users are now complaining that chrome v109 "scrolls too fast"

I use https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/chromium-wheel-smooth-scr/khpcanbeojalbkpgpmjpdkjnkfcgfkhb so I haven't noticed this :-)

(and now I retried your demo with the extension deactivated but it makes no difference)

> If anybody has a google account (I don't), please leave a comment on that bug report, about this leaflet PR

https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1406625#c22

The chromium folks might revert the scrollwheel behaviour (as per https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1406625#c26 ), so I think the best thing to do is to wait until the issue is resolved upstream (one way or the other).

Colors: Pink, Blue (Default), DarkBlue, Lila, Magenta, Red, Orange, Brown, Green, Mint

- `L.Icon.Default.DarkBlue()`
- `L.Icon.Default.Green()`
- ....

```
new Marker(latlng, {icon: new Icon.Default.Red()}).addTo(map);
```

comments: I have nearly no experience with ESM, can you please explain why this is needed?

> I have nearly no experience with ESM, can you please explain why this is needed?

The CORS policy for scripts loaded with `type=module` is different. So unlike regular scripts they will not load from the file-ystem directly. For example, if I open up one of the recently converted files in the debug section I get the following error:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/695720/218524760-58f5afd3-76a1-4a3d-b50a-19e383143541.png)

> The CORS policy for scripts loaded with `type=module` is different. So unlike regular scripts they will not load from the file-ystem directly. For example, if I open up one of the recently converted files in the debug section I get the following error:

Ou ok thank you ... now i like it even less 😄

agree with you @Falke-Design that not being able to load modules directly from the filesystem is annoying... does anyone know why this limitation exists? i assume there is a good reason but it's not immediately obvious to me and it didn't jump out on a quick glance at the [spec](https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-modules). see also: https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/8121. maybe this will change in the future?
more here https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/1888
the arguments there are pretty esoteric, not sure i can fully grasp them without more study but i guess i still prefer being forced to use an http server than non-standard build tools
It is what it is, having a HTTP server running is not the end of the world 😉

body: Replace for..in to avoid TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading 'lat') with extra attributes of array
comments: Can you provide an example of how to reproduce this bug?

I found it in a complicated piece o code, but the principle that caused
this bug was the following:

// Somewhere deep in your JavaScript library...Array.prototype.foo = 1;
// Now you have no idea what the below code will do.var a = [1, 2, 3,
4, 5];for (var x in a){
    // Now foo is a part of EVERY array and
    // will show up here as a value of 'x'.
    console.log(x);
}
/* Will display:
   0
   1
   2
   3
   4
   foo
*/


Jon Koops ***@***.***> escreveu em qui., 9/02/2023 às 18:59 :

> Can you provide an example of how to reproduce this bug?
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/pull/8840#issuecomment-1424672907>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAN4IKB4ZKFMGZJXO5RNDKLWWU5BPANCNFSM6AAAAAAUWYZWTA>
> .
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.Message ID:
> ***@***.***>
>
-- 
David Vaz, PhD

I am not too comfortable to create that. I just found a common error, and decided to warn about it. 

I literally changed 2 lines of code, easy to check by any reviewer. Can you please help?
even better. Perfect.
I have in mind that not all usages of `for ... in` can be replaced with `for ... of`, but else yeah makes maybe sense

> I have in mind that not all usages of `for ... in` can be replaced with `for ... of`, but else yeah makes maybe sense

Yeah I wonder how many we can replace and which will remain. I've created an issue for it (#8843) with a 'help wanted' label, since it's not really high prio, but should be looked into by someone.

body: Hi all, I know this is a massive PR and so I'm not necessarily expecting you'll want to merge it but I thought it might be worth pointing out to those who might be interested (https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/8352).
comments:
In its current state, Leaflet is REALLY close to working out of the box without any bundling via `import * as L from '/node_modules/leaflet/src/Leaflet.js'` or even just `import * as L from 'leaflet'` with an import-map. Personally, I find not having to mess with build tooling makes the development experience just that much more magical. All that's needed is to import real file names (use .js extension) and avoid attempting to import JSON files (which are not ES modules).

My first commit here just adds the .js extensions (easy enough with a sed one liner), and the second hardcodes the version number in Leaflet.js, and that's it!

Hi @jessetane, we're definitely interested in landing as close as possible support for ESM without the need for bundling. Part of this is adding the `.js` extensions. Before we land something like this I'd like to enforce this like a configuration for Rollup and ESLint rules, could you look into that?

I'm not super familiar with eslint but it looks like this plugin https://github.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/blob/main/docs/rules/extensions.md does what you want, see [8a5d712](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/pull/8837/commits/8a5d7128bd914547fed61f31f4e74c40355a471f)
Oops, that got a little weird due to package-lock being checked in... if you want the lockfile change in a commit I can send it, just lmk

@jonkoops I saw https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/pull/8838 and realized a file server is necessary to demonstrate "native" module loading as I was describing. I just pushed two more commits here as an example.

Happy to trim this PR down if any of the particular commits are useful to you - sounds like just [72da14e](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/pull/8837/commits/72da14e3317c351facaf8fe34ff2fb9bcf1fd714) and [8a5d712](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/pull/8837/commits/8a5d7128bd914547fed61f31f4e74c40355a471f) at this point? Like I say this was mostly about bringing the topic up for discussion!
Yeah, that should pretty much cover it. Thanks @jessetane!
rebased
Thanks @jessetane!

body:
Drops the UMD (Universal Module Definition) distribution and makes ESM (ECMAScript modules) distribution the default. Also changes the default [type of the package](https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#type) to `module` so that all code in the repository is evaluated as ESM by Node.js.

Since ESM is now the default all files with the `.mjs` extension have been renamed to `.js`. Some configuration files such as those for Karma and ESLint do not yet support ESM fully, so these have been renamed to `.cjs` to remain functional.
comments: Hmmm, yeah. Looks like I'll have to port those over first. I wanted to clean up that code anyways so I will open up some PRs to do so.
Converting this to a draft until I have all the aforementioned issues resolved.
@jonkoops @IvanSanchez @mourner please review
I am currently a bit bogged down with the day job, but I will try and get a review in for you this week @Falke-Design. Thanks for picking this back up.

@jonkoops @Falke-Design  I'm looking at https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/blob/7ac98758d4eb5c2389afa01566aeb4c352abe026/.github/workflows/main.yml#L181 , but I know nothing about how S3 works (IIRC it was @mourner who set the S3 accounts long time ago).

Updated the S3 bucket so that there's no error, but now it complains that there's no `dist` folder to upload. 😅 I think we can just remove the job, and make sure to update the download page (and rename it to "Get started", "Install" or something) after v2 is out.

body:
Moves the `callInitHooks()` method to the prototype of `Class` instead of defining it every time a class is `extend()`ed. The method is also re-implemented to remove the reliance on variables defined in the scope of `extend()`.

Part of a series of PRs to land the work from #8806 for standardized ECMAScript classes incrementally.
commit_messages: Move `callInitHooks()` to prototype of `Class` (#8825)

body:
Changes the logic for inheritance of `Class` to use the more modern [`Object.setPrototypeOf()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Object/setPrototypeOf). The same method is now used to 'inherit' the static properties of a parent class, rather than copying it over manually.

Part of a series of PRs to land the work from #8806 for standardized ECMAScript classes incrementally.
commit_messages: Use `Object.setPrototypeOf()` to extend `Class` (#8824)

body:
Destructures `statics` and `includes` from class properties. This avoids the need to delete these fields from the prototype after extending.
 
 Part of a series of PRs to land the work from #8806 for standardized ECMAScript classes incrementally.
commit_messages: Destructure `statics` and `includes` from class properties (#8823)

body:
Bumps [activesupport](https://github.com/rails/rails) from 6.0.6 to 6.0.6.1.
Release notes

Sourced from activesupport's releases.

v6.0.6.1

Active Support

  • No changes.

Active Model

  • No changes.

Active Record

  • Make sanitize_as_sql_comment more strict

    Though this method was likely never meant to take user input, it was attempting sanitization. That sanitization could be bypassed with carefully crafted input.

    This commit makes the sanitization more robust by replacing any occurrances of "/" or "/" with "/ " or " /". It also performs a first pass to remove one surrounding comment to avoid compatibility issues for users relying on the existing removal.

    This also clarifies in the documentation of annotate that it should not be provided user input.

    [CVE-2023-22794]

Action View

  • No changes.

Action Pack

  • No changes.

Active Job

  • No changes.

body:
Replaces the custom animation frame API from `Util` with the standardized methods. These are now available in all browsers within our support target, so there is no longer required to use a polyfill.

This removes the following APIs:
- `Util.requestAnimFrame()`
- `Util.cancelAnimFrame()`
- `Util.requestFn`
- `Util.cancelFn`
comments: I believe it might have something to do with how Sinon handles [fake timers](https://github.com/sinonjs/fake-timers/blob/main/README.md).
@mourner related to your recent changes under #9241 and #9236.

~don't understand why the test `auto invalidateSize after container resize` is failling on the server but not locally ...~
Some file was wrong in the cache ...
Nice work! Thanks for getting this landed @Falke-Design!

Looks pretty good for me. If we have no hurry I would like to test it with some "plugins" in the next days.

For me as a reminder to test: `instanceof`, `typeof`

> Looks pretty good for me. If we have no hurry I would like to test it with some "plugins" in the next days.

We're in no rush, I wanted to get this out there to get some early feedback and explore our options. Feel free to test it against some plugins if you like, but things might still be prone to change.

This is going to be somewhat tricky to get right. Ultimately I'd like to get rid of all the `.extend()` calls, or at least move **all** the functionality to the `constructor` of the base `class Class`.

The 'problem' is that `this` will always refer to the child class, and never the parent class it makes which impossible to get the prototype of the 'current' class.

As [per MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Inheritance_and_the_prototype_chain#inheriting_methods):
> When an inherited function is executed, the value of [this](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/this) points to the inheriting object, not to the prototype object where the function is an own property.


So I think any approach that goes against the stream is here is kinda dead on arrival. I was thinking what we could do instead is place the `callInitHooks()` in parent class `Class`, and directly traverse the prototype itself in reverse. This would replicate the existing functionality, but remove the need for super calls.
Remember https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/super#super-calling_static_methods , folks.
@IvanSanchez I plan to move this from `NewClass` into the `Class` prototype, so there would be no need for a `super()` call anymore.
@jonkoops looks good and all tests are passing 👍
Added the refactored method, however moving stuff to `Class` still breaks the tests :thinking:

> however moving stuff to `Class` still breaks the tests 🤔

How does the code look like then?
Ok, I managed to move the hook initialization to the base class `Class`. Also `NewClass` now properly uses the `extends` keywork to extend `Class`.

I'm converting this PR to a draft. I think it's a good place to work on and discuss this feature, but I see more benefit in chunking the work for this PR out into several smaller pieces of work that are easier to review.
Closing this, since all the changes seem to have been merged via five individual PRs.
Yeah, there are still a couple things left. But I feel this PR does not serve a useful purpose at this point.

body: Removes the `__super__` property from classes. This [was used in CoffeeScript](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/commit/c3ee79b01d44484745fe59e91be88b1b502bd80e) to determine the super class in their own class system, but has since been superseded by [standardized ECMAScript classes](https://coffeescript.org/#classes).
comments: This dates back to https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/commit/c3ee79b01d44484745fe59e91be88b1b502bd80e and https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/commit/ff72181b52e323d21d495b1d8691257a1aa8d6eb - it's not a deprecated JS feature, but a coffeescript convention instead. I guess it's meant to keep track of whether a class is a `L.Class` or a vanilla JS `function`/`class`/`Object`.

Ahhh, looks like I wasn't paying attention when going through this code and I mistook the two. I'm working to refactor the class system so we can make use of standardized classes in some manner.

I'd still like to get rid of this, as it looks like CoffeeScript has moved to [using standardized classes](https://coffeescript.org/#classes) since version 2.

> I'm working to refactor the class system so we can make use of standardized classes in some manner.

@jonkoops is it still possible to `include` and `extend` a class?

> @jonkoops is it still possible to `include` and `extend` a class?

Standard ES6 classes have `extend` built in. For Leaflet's `include`, it should be possible to port the current technique in the form of a static method that modifies the class prototype.

> Standard ES6 classes have `extend` built in. For Leaflet's `include`, it should be possible to port the current technique in the form of a static method that modifies the class prototype.

Note that that the prototype of ECMAScript classes is non-configurable, so changing it's prototype will require some [tomfoolery](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/37680766/how-to-change-classs-prototype-in-es6#answer-37680991) (honestly a better API anyways).

> Is it still possible to include and extend a class?

Ideally I'd like to keep all of the existing functionality of our `Class` system and deprecate them so that we're not breaking things too much in the next major. We can consider them for removal in the next version.

However if I run into any impediments I will make sure to raise them so they can be discussed.
commit_messages: Drop  `__super__` property from Class (#8800)

body:
To determine the left mouse button we used [which](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/UIEvent/which) but it is deprecated. So we need to use [button](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MouseEvent/button). We already have it implemented but for some reason we had `exit if button !== 1` which means it is only true if the middle mouse button is used.

`which`:

    0: No button
    1: Left button
    2: Middle button (if present)
    3: Right button

`button`:

    0: Main button pressed, usually the left button or the un-initialized state
    1: Auxiliary button pressed, usually the wheel button or the middle button (if present)
    2: Secondary button pressed, usually the right button
    3: Fourth button, typically the Browser Back button
    4: Fifth button, typically the Browser Forward button


@mourner this was already implemented a long time ago but you reverted it, do you maybe have an idea why?
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19800037/212394053-314a5fc4-9d1c-4388-907f-0e9e4c4cd248.png)

https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/commit/0d1716d7964491ae894b58ef006cda9dd07d078f
https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/commit/21a748123f7411ed8a0be5824e2366b71c7b6b8b
comments: @Falke-Design yep, traced it — reverted because it broke IE8, but we don't care anymore. https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/pull/3287#issuecomment-82901827
Loving all this old cruft removal :muscle:
commit_messages: Remove deprecated `which` and change `button` to main-button (#8796)

body:
### Background

First I'd like to thank @mourner for the fix in #8103, which makes it work when `zoomAnimation` is `true`.

However, as mentioned in #7466, #8644, and my https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/pull/8103#issuecomment-1235646390, it doesn't work when `zoomAnimation` is set as `false`.
You can refer to the test case `debug/vector/vector-drift.html` added in this PR to reproduce or the [online demo](https://plnkr.co/edit/qHqGIded24Z4MYtO) provided by #7466.

In this PR, I tried to set the `transform-origin` as `0 0` for the container of the SVG/Canvas renderer. By default, it might be `center`. I'm not sure if it is right way to fix this bug but it works indeed and looks simple.

closes #8117

### Comparison

| Platform | Before | After |
| :----: | :----: | :----: |
| Desktop | ![bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26999792/212246047-eb813b21-93d1-4144-aa29-046d64af27f0.gif) | ![fixed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26999792/212246079-424489de-4267-42d7-a0d7-56c59d82a69c.gif) 
| Mobile | ![bug-mobile](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26999792/212246191-9af72c81-6de3-4ff4-9661-2cecd763b151.gif) | ![fixed-mobile](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26999792/212246209-99fd3c6d-a070-4710-b0c0-b6c9c9ea21b0.gif) |
comments: @plainheart the fix looks great, thank you for looking into this! Since it's not covered by tests currently, I wonder if it would be covered by #8644 — can you take a look? Let's see if it passes if we turn zoomAnimation off there with this fix applied, and fails without.
I'm not familiar with how to add test cases, so I'd like to ask you to help me to add some appropriate test cases. Thanks!
@plainheart oh, I mean there's already a test case written in that PR — we just need to check if it still passes with zoomAnimation: false and this fix.

The reason why this is working is because dragging is prevented:
https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/blob/9793d0ab1ca545e5a578c9451f84a908d3e7ce08/src/dom/Draggable.js#L81
Would love to see this in the next release. +1

body:
For small areas, the center was to far away of the layer. It looks like the reason are rounding errors (Thx to turf.js for the idea: https://github.com/Turfjs/turf/blob/master/packages/turf-center-of-mass/index.ts#L39). But this solution doesn't work good for normal / larger areas, so I added a check if the area of the bounds are small then `1700` it using the rounding preventing solution.

To solve this I needed to add the new function `PolyUtil.centroid`.

This needs merged in the `main` banche too.

error:
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19800037/211090134-ce69fd79-5b93-4dbf-9d68-620f04174d68.png)

fixed:
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19800037/211090702-518f3eb8-29cc-4659-af95-96a1a4b9ece4.png)

```
L.polygon([[42.87097909758862, -81.12594320566181], [42.87108302016597, -81.12594320566181], [42.87108302016597, -81.12576504805303], [42.87097909758862, -81.12576504805303]]).addTo(map);
```

Fixes #8783

PS: I also cleaned up some unnecessary tests.
comments: We should release this fix. @mourner @jonkoops @IvanSanchez can you please review.
commit_messages: Fix rounding errors in center calculation for small layers (#8784)

body: Closes #8756
comments:
There are a couple of unresolved issues which is why I have marked this PR as a draft.

Firstly, there is no SVG version of the marker shadow. I don't have much experience designing these sort of things so I would appreciate it if someone could create an SVG version of this asset.

I am also considering the idea of removing the shadow image, and instead using the [`drop-shadow`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/filter-function/drop-shadow) CSS filter. Which should automatically create shadows in the correct shape for 3rd party icons as well, without needing additional assets.

Secondly, it looks like the SVG version of the marker does not have the hole on the top filled in white (see below). Something that is present in the bitmap version.

![The SVG verrsion of the marker icon, without white fill.](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/695720/210135476-4a455ee4-a35c-415d-bd45-96453763dd1a.png)

WDYT?

Before landing this change, we should make sure it has no implications on performance when using a lot of markers on screen at once (e.g. thousands), and check in Blink, Webkit and Firefox since they are optimized differently with regards to rendering SVG.

Also, it would be nice to explore how the new markers could styled with CSS — e.g. add classes to some of the marker elements so that we could pass a className to a marker that we can target to make it red instead of blue.

> Also, it would be nice to explore how the new markers could styled with CSS — e.g. add classes to some of the marker elements so that we could pass a className to a marker that we can target to make it red instead of blue.

We could probably use CSS variables for this even. However I do believe this would require us to in-line the SVG either way (vs. loading it as an image). Not sure what the performance implications of that would be.
@Falke-Design `flyTo` duration should be approximately the same regardless of performance. I'd measure number of frames instead (relative to theoretical maximum, which is `duration * 60`).

> > Also, it would be nice to explore how the new markers could styled with CSS — e.g. add classes to some of the marker elements so that we could pass a className to a marker that we can target to make it red instead of blue.
> 
> We could probably use CSS variables for this even. However I do believe this would require us to in-line the SVG either way (vs. loading it as an image). Not sure what the performance implications of that would be.

From experience inline SVG are terribly slow. I've had to convert them to base64 in one of my projects

Yes, I do believe that SVGs inside of `img` elements will have some performance benefits, I am quite sure they can be cached more aggressively in the rendering process. However this still needs to be tested properly.
@mourner @jonkoops @IvanSanchez what is needed to merge this? I don't know how to make good performance tests, maybe someone else can do it (if needed)?

body: Refactoring happen.js to make `pointer` events available
comments: @Falke-Design Gentle reminder that https://github.com/Leaflet/prosthetic-hand exists and does pointer events.

> @Falke-Design Gentle reminder that https://github.com/Leaflet/prosthetic-hand exists and does pointer events.

Is there an easy way without creating a Finger to simulate the event? Like `once(elem, 'keypress')`

> 1. I'd really like to avoid any libraries vendored in the Leaflet repo. A more standard course of action would be to fork the library, make changes there through PRs so that it's clear what changed, publish it on NPM namespaced and then use it as a dependency.
> 2. You'd need to update your NPM version so that the lockfile doesn't downgrade from v2 to v1.

1. I thought about that but I don't want to maintaine this repo, so I thought I add only the necessary code for Leaflet. Not that in a few years the repo is unmaintained again.
2. ups, will be changed :+1:

Perhaps we can refactor the tests so that `happen` can be removed and only `prosthetic-hand` is used? I haven't yet intimately familiarized myself  with these libraries, but it looks like `happen` is pretty much dead.

So either that, or we create a very light-weight wrapper to quickly simulate pointer events only. No need to pull in a whole library.

WDYT?

I outsourced the code into https://github.com/Falke-Design/ui-event-simulator.

Maybe I oversee something but I don't think that `prosthetic-hand` is the right tool to simulate simple and all variants of events. If there is a way please provide a PR until then I suggest to merge this PR. 

This is needed to proceed with #7200.

> Maybe I oversee something but I don't think that `prosthetic-hand` is the right tool to simulate simple and all variants of events. If there is a way please provide a PR until then I suggest to merge this PR.

You're right - `prosthetic-hand` is good for a succession of `PointerEvent`s, but cannot do individual `KeyboardEvent`s.
@mourner @IvanSanchez shall we move this one along, or are there any objections?
Merging this in so we can continue our work.

body: Removes the `Browser.canvas` API  to detect HTML canvas support. Our new browser support target will always support this feature, so it is no longer required to detect it.
comments:
> This makes the `prefer` in [preferCanvas](https://leafletjs.com/reference.html#map-prefercanvas) obsolete.

I don't think it does, as the code that determines the renderer [still exists](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/blob/9f35179419aad62d5d735f49a70e7a79fd67cfd5/src/layer/vector/Renderer.getRenderer.js#L39-L44). That said, do we want to change the default here or perhaps even get rid of one of the renderers?

> That said, do we want to change the default here or perhaps even get rid of one of the renderers?

I think the default is just fine - most use cases get covered by `SVG`, and some minor use caseswork better with `Canvas`. Removing `Canvas` might be too much for plugin authors, even with the whole 2.0 breaking changes.

I'd propose renaming `preferCanvas = true` to `preferredRenderer = L.Canvas` (`L.` just for the sake of clarity, I know we're getting away from the namespace and into `import`s). Ideally I'd like to put some finishing touches on [Gleo](https://gitlab.com/IvanSanchez/gleo) and make it a Leaflet WebGL vector renderer. Having a `preferredRenderer` map option would allow for hot-plugging the fabled WebGL rendering backend.

> > This makes the `prefer` in [preferCanvas](https://leafletjs.com/reference.html#map-prefercanvas) obsolete.
> 
> I don't think it does, as the code that determines the renderer [still exists](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/blob/9f35179419aad62d5d735f49a70e7a79fd67cfd5/src/layer/vector/Renderer.getRenderer.js#L39-L44). That said, do we want to change the default here or perhaps even get rid of one of the renderers?

It makes sense to have a flag that the user can decide if he wants to render everything as canvas or svg. But before `preferCanvas` checked if canvas is possible for the browser else use svg. Now it will be always rendered as cavas, so the option `useCanvas` would make more sense instead of `preferCanvas`.

No need to change the option name, I only wanted to show that `prefer` is maybe not accurate anymore

> Having a `preferredRenderer` map option would allow for hot-plugging the fabled WebGL rendering backend.

Doesn't `Map` already have a [`renderer`](https://leafletjs.com/reference.html#map-renderer) option? That would allow us to do this?

I think we should perhaps get rid of `preferCanvas` as an option, it's confusing to me what renderer would be used. I'd much rather only see an explicit `renderer` option.

> Now it will be always rendered as canvas, so the option `useCanvas` would make more sense instead of `preferCanvas`.

Are you sure? The [change in this PR](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/pull/8754/files#diff-f4127fe2c74bbf5c584e01246849fac1954ead8521449585b61d268bfb7b059eL493) should only affect the fallback to SVG when using `L.canvas()`. The conditional logic that picks the renderer for the map [still depends](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/blob/9f35179419aad62d5d735f49a70e7a79fd67cfd5/src/layer/vector/Renderer.getRenderer.js#L43) on `preferCanvas`, which by default is falsy.

So unless I am missing something I do believe the default renderer is SVG based, no?

> > Having a `preferredRenderer` map option would allow for hot-plugging the fabled WebGL rendering backend.
> 
> Doesn't `Map` already have a [`renderer`](https://leafletjs.com/reference.html#map-renderer) option? That would allow us to do this?
> 
> I think we should perhaps get rid of `preferCanvas` as an option, it's confusing to me what renderer would be used. I'd much rather only see an explicit `renderer` option.

Yeah I think that makes sense

> > Now it will be always rendered as canvas, so the option `useCanvas` would make more sense instead of `preferCanvas`.
> 
> Are you sure? The [change in this PR](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/pull/8754/files#diff-f4127fe2c74bbf5c584e01246849fac1954ead8521449585b61d268bfb7b059eL493) should only affect the fallback to SVG when using `L.canvas()`. The conditional logic that picks the renderer for the map [still depends](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/blob/9f35179419aad62d5d735f49a70e7a79fd67cfd5/src/layer/vector/Renderer.getRenderer.js#L43) on `preferCanvas`, which by default is falsy.
> 
> So unless I am missing something I do believe the default renderer is SVG based, no?

Sorry, my explanation is getting worse and worse 😅 I try it again.
With `preferCanvas` (old behaviour) we have a flag when is set to `true`, checks if the browser supports canvas. If the browser support canvas then use canvas, else use svg.
Now (new behaviour) the check `Browser.canvas` was removed so there is no **_prefer_** anymore, it is **_use_** or **_not use_** canvas.
Gotcha, yeah that is correct. What would y'all think about removing `preferCanvas` entirely and using the provided `renderer` from options instead?

body:
Changes the implementation of `DomUtil.disableTextSelection()` and `DomUtil.enableTextSelection()` to exclusively use the [`user-select`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/user-select) CSS property.

Previously this was detecting the `selectstart` event and then using `event.preventDefault()` to ensure the user was not able to select text. This approach however was flawed as Safari on iOS now supports this event, but does not prevent the user from selecting text when the event is prevented.

Also fixes a bug where it was possible to call `DomUtil.disableTextSelection()` twice in a row allowing the internal value for restoring text selection to be incorrectly set to `none`. This then caused `DomUtil.enableTextSelection()` to 'restore' this incorrect value.

Documentation for `DomUtil.disableImageDrag()` and `DomUtil.enableImageDrag()` has also been adjusted as it contained a incorrect references.

Closes #8740
comments:
Some cross browser testing would be appreciated before merging this one. I've tested this on iOS and macOS Safari (16.2), Firefox (macOS 108.0.1) and Chrome (macOS 108.0.5359.124).

I've added a test HTML file for debugging purposes (see `debug/tests/text-selection.html`).

> Some cross browser testing would be appreciated before merging this one. I've tested this on iOS and macOS Safari (16.2), Firefox (macOS 108.0.1) and Chrome (macOS 108.0.5359.124).
> 
> I've added a test HTML file for debugging purposes (see `debug/tests/text-selection.html`).

Tested via BrowserStack:
Win 10 & Win 11, Chrome 108, Edge 108, Firefox 108: working
Mac Monterey: Safari 15.6, Chrome 108, Edge 108, Firefox 108: working

Do you know why the Windows Chrome CI fails? Haven't seen this error before:

```
'karma' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.
Error: Process completed with exit code 1.
```

> Do you know why the Windows Chrome CI fails? Haven't seen this error before:

It seems to happen on the latest commit on `main` as well, perhaps something has changed in GitHub actions?
Got a fix for the failures on CI under #8742, they are unrelated to the changes in this PR.
@Falke-Design can we merge this one as far as you are concerned?
commit_messages: Fix implementation for disabling & enabling text selection (#8741)

body: Removes `DomUtil.testProp()` which was previously used to test for vendor-prefixed styles. Now that we have a more modern browser support target this is no longer required.
commit_messages: Remove `DomUtil.testProp()` (#8739)

body: Removes vendor prefixes for `userSelect` style when disabling or re-enabling text selection. Since this property is now supported by all major browsers it's no longer required to add a vendor prefix.
comments:
I feel like the `disableTextSelection` and `enableTextSelection` functions could be optimized further. The only browser that does not seem to implement the `selectstart` event is Safari on iOS (see [MDN docs](url)).

Not sure if this info is up-to-date, but I have a gut feeling this could still be optimized. Perhaps by only using `user-select`, since the property is supported everywhere.

Either way, it would require further investigation I can't get into right now.

@jonkoops I was wary about this change before because [MDN states](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/user-select) `user-select` is still prefixed on Safari (both desktop and mobile). Can you please confirm we didn't break it there by removing the prefix?
commit_messages: Remove vendor prefixes when setting `userSelect` style (#8738)

body:
After adding `coords[0].slice()` in #7344 we have the problem that if `coords[0]` is `undefined` an error is thrown.

Must released in `1.9.4`
comments: Cherry pick into `v1` done: https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/commit/f42cab93c30a33828ecbc753febb3247a069c8c3
Does this warrant a release or should we hold off until we have gathered more bugfixes?
I would wait a month or two and then release it.
commit_messages: `toGeoJSON()` should still work if no values in coords array (#8737)

body: Removes the `DomUtil.empty()` function and replaces it with the standard [`Element.replaceChildren()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/replaceChildren) method.
commit_messages: Replace `DomUtil.empty()` with `Element.replaceChildren()` (#8736)

body:
Removes the `DomUtil.remove()` function and replaces it with the standard [`Element.remove()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/remove) method. `DomUtil.remove()` was a polyfill, which is no longer required now that we have raised our target browsers.

This also removes `DomUtil.remove()` as an API, thus this is a breaking change.
commit_messages: Replace `DomUtil.remove()` with `Element.remove()` (#8735)

body: Removes the `TRANSITION` and `TRANSITION_END` constants from `DomUtil`. Previously this would ensure the correct vendor prefixes were used for the CSS properties, but it is no longer required now that we have raised our target browsers.
commit_messages: Remove `TRANSITION` and `TRANSITION_END` constants from `DomUtil` (#8734)

body: Removes the `DomUtil.TRANSFORM` constant. Previously this would ensure the correct vendor prefix was used for the CSS property, but it is no longer required now that we have raised our target browsers.
commit_messages: Remove `DomUtil.TRANSFORM` constant (#8733)

body:
Removes the `DomUtil.removeClass()` function and replaces it with the standard [`classList.remove()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/classList) method. `DomUtil.removeClass()` was a polyfill, which is no longer required now that we have raised our target browsers.

This also removes `DomUtil.removeClass()` as an API, thus this is a breaking change. See #8685 for more background information.
comments: Looks like Bundlemon is having some issues, but it should not be affected by the changes in this PR.

> Looks like Bundlemon is having some issues, but it should not be affected by the changes in this PR.

@LironEr anything going on on your side? I don't quite understand why this is failing now.
commit_messages: Replace `DomUtil.removeClass()` with `classList.remove()` (#8732)

body:
Removes the `DomUtil.addClass()` function and replaces it with the standard [`classList.add()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/classList) method. `DomUtil.addClass()` was a polyfill, which is no longer required now that we have raised our target browsers.

This also removes `DomUtil.addClass()` as an API, thus this is a breaking change. See #8685 for more background information.
commit_messages: Replace `DomUtil.addClass()` with `classList.add()` (#8731)

body: Also joining in on the fun of removing code. 😊 Removes `DomUtil` `setOpacity`, which was a polyfill for IE, but it's no longer needed in v2. This is a breaking change.
commit_messages: Remove `DomUtil.setOpacity` (#8730)

body:
Removes the `DomUtil.setClass()` function, users should set the [`classList.value`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/classList) property instead. `DomUtil.setClass()` was a polyfill, which is no longer required now that we have raised our target browsers.

This removes `DomUtil.setClass()` as an API, thus this is a breaking change. See #8685 for more background information.
commit_messages: Remove `DomUtil.setClass()` method (#8729)

body:
Removes the `DomUtil.getClass()` function and replaces it with the standard [`classList.value`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/classList) property. `DomUtil.getClass()` was a polyfill, which is no longer required now that we have raised our target browsers.

This also remove `DomUtil.getClass()` as an API, thus this is a breaking change. See #8685 for more background information.
commit_messages: Replace `DomUtil.getClass()` with `classList.value` (#8728)

body:
Removes the `DomUtil.hasClass()` function and replaces it with the standard [`classList.contains()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/classList) method. `DomUtil.hasClass()` was a polyfill, which is no longer required now that we have raised our target browsers.

This also remove `DomUtil.hasClass()` as an API, thus this is a breaking change. See #8685 for more background information.
commit_messages: Replace `DomUtil.hasClass()` with `classList.contains()` (#8727)

Nice work! Nit: can we do anything about the errored badges? Seeing a bunch of those on the page (not sure if it's intermittent or permanent for a particular plugin):
Loving this change, this makes it a lot easier for folks to judge the quality of these plugins!

> Nice work! Nit: can we do anything about the errored badges? Seeing a bunch of those on the page (not sure if it's intermittent or permanent for a particular plugin):

@mourner sadly sometimes the badge generation doesn't work correct, but after a refesh of the page it should work and then it is in the cache for 24h on the server. https://badgen.net/
This makes it now visible that the biggest Leaflet hype was between 5 and 7 years ago. 😄

Bumps [nokogiri](https://github.com/sparklemotion/nokogiri) from 1.13.9 to 1.13.10.
Release notes

Sourced from nokogiri's releases.

1.13.10 / 2022-12-07

Security

  • [CRuby] Address CVE-2022-23476, unchecked return value from xmlTextReaderExpand. See GHSA-qv4q-mr5r-qprj for more information.

Improvements

  • [CRuby] XML::Reader#attribute_hash now returns nil on parse errors. This restores the behavior of #attributes from v1.13.7 and earlier. [#2715]

body:
I sent a pull request for a small change which I think is very useful and many people
The main reason why I decided to implement it directly in the codebase and send it as PR is because every time you need this function the code needed to do it out of the library is always dirty and inconvenient and then I think it is a consistent method with what is expected from the L.Latlng object.

Opinions are welcome

thank you all
Stef
comments:
For what do you need to modify the precision on the `LatLng` object? I think working with exact values and setting the precision while exporting is more efficient.
But I'm open if you let me know some usecases.

Edit: 
- One usecase would be calculations. For example comparing two coords with precision 12 can return in a different result then with precision 6.
- Plugins mostly don't allow to set precision in theier API. This function would it make easier for the developer to set precision and then pass the LatLng object to the plugin.
Closing this due to lack of reaction from the PR author. Feel free to let me know if this needs to be re-opened.

body: Enforces the [`quotes`](https://eslint.org/docs/latest/rules/quotes) rule for files in the `spec` directory, just like the rest of the code. Not quite sure why this was disabled in the first place, but it seems good to keep things consistent.
commit_messages: Enforce `quotes` ESLint rule for the `spec` directory (#8686)

body:
Changes the methods for class manipulation (`hasClass`, `addClass`, `removeClass`, `setClass` and `getClass`) in `DomUtil` to use the [`classList` API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/classList) exclusively. Includes the following changes:

- Changes the type annotation to use the `Element` class, from which both `HTMLElement` and `SVGElement` extend.
- Updates the documentation for these methods to be more unified and explicit.
- Drops Internet Explorer specific hack for getting a class name.
- Drops deprecated usage of the [`SVGElement.className` property](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/SVGElement#svgelement.classname).
- Improves testing coverage by testing both `HTMLElement` and `SVGElement` and splitting out the test cases.

Although I think this is a nice cleanup, most of these methods are now light-weight wrappers around the `classList` API. So lightweight in fact that we might as well use this API directly.

Therefore, before merging this PR I would like to know from the core members if we are perhaps better off without these methods for 2.0.
comments:
Note that I am in favor of removing these methods entirely for version 2.0. I think we should aim to align Leaflet as much as possible with the Web API, instead of putting our own shims around it.

I was thinking that perhaps we can add a `leaflet-compat` package that holds all of these APIs we are removing for v2 so that folks can migrate over at their own pace. WDYT?

Out of my eyes as a plugin developer removing APIs are bad. They force me to change my code. On the other hand Leaflet, should not take care about Util functionality which are built-in in browsers.
Another problem with removing the Util functions are that we lose compatibility for many plugins which are not maintained anymore. 
**So I see no way around creating an additional script for migration.** For me personally I would not name it `leaflet-compat`. I think better would be the full name `leaflet-compatibility` or another name. Let us also thinking about including it as static file in the dist folder.

Unrelated to this, I am also considering we should move all of the official Leaflet plugins into a mono-repo with our code . That way we can test them together with the Leaflet code to catch regressions and compatibility issues early on.

> What are the offical Leaflet plugins for you? I don't see this compatible with the light-weight mindset of Leaflet. Also we have already enough work with Leaflet core without the plugins.

It's the ones under the Leaflet organization on GitHub, but this is a discussion for another time.

> I would prefer to create an additional script which needs to be imported too. 

I think a lot of folks just want their plugins to 'just work', as if it's a drop in replacement then it can be used as an alias (such as [in WebPack](https://webpack.js.org/configuration/resolve/#resolvealias)).

> It's the ones under the Leaflet organization on GitHub, but this is a discussion for another time.

But I hope you don't want to inlcude the big libraries like Leaflet-Draw or Markercluster, neither the other not maintained ones (Leaflet.Editable, Leaflet.heat, Path.Drag.js, Leaflet.toolbar). 

> I think a lot of folks just want their plugins to 'just work'

Yes that is very important. I see the benifit in own script, that we don't have to care in later release about it. We can make now a clear cut and everyone who needs the old utilities, can include the seperate script too. But it is also ok for me to make `leaflet/compat`
Let's merge this in for now, I think we can always have a separate discussion about how we're going to handle compatibility in the future.

> Therefore, before merging this PR I would like to know from the core members if we are perhaps better off without these methods for 2.0.

The way I see it, when we're talking about deprecating APIs like this, there's no better chance for dropping them than a new major version (v2), so we better cram all the ones we want before the release. It's not like we can keep a 100% compatibility anyway — we dropped some methods already (e.g. those in `Util`) and didn't provide a compat wrapper for those, which breaks consistency.

Besides, plugins would likely have to be updated for v2 compatibility anyway (because of ES stuff, etc.). Ideally we would urge plugin developers to upgrade the plugins, maybe make a "v2 compatible" badge bubbling plugins to the top in the docs, and avoid having to maintain a "compatibility" layer forever, staying lean.
Yeah, I agree with that. I'll see what it would take to remove these functions.
Created the first PR in the series under #8727. I think we could possibly provide users with a [codemod](https://github.com/facebook/jscodeshift) to automate the migration process.
commit_messages: Use the `classList` API for class manipulation methods in `DomUtil` (#8685)

body:
Replaces calls to `Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty()` with it's intended replacement [`Object.hasOwn()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Object/hasOwn). This results in less and more readable code.

Also includes a linting rule to enforce this preference.
commit_messages: Prefer `Object.hasOwn()` over `Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty()` (#8684)

body:
Removes the `Util.isArray()` function and replaces it with the standard [`Array.isArray()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/isArray) method. `Util.isArray()` was a polyfill, which is no longer required now that we have raised our target browsers.

This also remove `Util.isArray()` as an API, thus this is a breaking change.
commit_messages: Replace `Util.isArray()` with `Array.isArray()` (#8683)

body:
Removes the `Util.trim()` function and replaces it with the standard [`String.prototype.trim()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/trim) method. `Util.trim()` was a polyfill, which is no longer required now that we have raised our target browsers.

This also remove `Util.trim()` as an API, thus this is a breaking change.
commit_messages: Replace `Util.trim()` with `String.prototype.trim()` (#8682)

body:
Removes the `Util.create()` function and replaces it with the standard [`Object.create()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Object/create) method. `Util.create()` was a polyfill, which is no longer required now that we have raised our target browsers.

This also remove `Util.create()` as an API, thus this is a breaking change.
commit_messages: Replace `Util.create()` with `Object.create()` (#8681)
