Bumps [engine.io](https://github.com/socketio/engine.io) from 6.2.0 to 6.2.1.
Release notes

Sourced from engine.io's releases.

6.2.1

:warning: This release contains an important security fix :warning:

A malicious client could send a specially crafted HTTP request, triggering an uncaught exception and killing the Node.js process:

Error: read ECONNRESET
    at TCP.onStreamRead (internal/stream_base_commons.js:209:20)
Emitted 'error' event on Socket instance at:
    at emitErrorNT (internal/streams/destroy.js:106:8)
    at emitErrorCloseNT (internal/streams/destroy.js:74:3)
    at processTicksAndRejections (internal/process/task_queues.js:80:21) {
  errno: -104,
  code: 'ECONNRESET',
  syscall: 'read'
}

Please upgrade as soon as possible.

Bug Fixes

  • catch errors when destroying invalid upgrades (#658) (425e833)
Changelog

Sourced from engine.io's changelog.

6.2.1 (2022-11-20)

:warning: This release contains an important security fix :warning:

A malicious client could send a specially crafted HTTP request, triggering an uncaught exception and killing the Node.js process:

Error: read ECONNRESET
    at TCP.onStreamRead (internal/stream_base_commons.js:209:20)
Emitted 'error' event on Socket instance at:
    at emitErrorNT (internal/streams/destroy.js:106:8)
    at emitErrorCloseNT (internal/streams/destroy.js:74:3)
    at processTicksAndRejections (internal/process/task_queues.js:80:21) {
  errno: -104,
  code: 'ECONNRESET',
  syscall: 'read'
}

Please upgrade as soon as possible.

Bug Fixes

  • catch errors when destroying invalid upgrades (#658) (425e833)

3.6.0 (2022-06-06)

Bug Fixes

  • add extension in the package.json main entry (#608) (3ad0567)
  • do not reset the ping timer after upgrade (1f5d469), closes socketio/socket.io-client-swift#1309

Features

  • decrease the default value of maxHttpBufferSize (58e274c)

This change reduces the default value from 100 mb to a more sane 1 mb.

This helps protect the server against denial of service attacks by malicious clients sending huge amounts of data.

See also: https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-j4f2-536g-r55m

  • increase the default value of pingTimeout (f55a79a)

body:
I noticed the use of the parameter name `closed` in `latLngsToCoords` when looking at the changes or PR #7344.

But I got confused on what the usage is regarding this parameter as it suggests (because on the fact it's a noun) it states something about the current 'status' of the coords (`latlngs` parameter) being passed to the function.

Therefore I think it's better to change the name to `close`...
comments:
> It is named closed because the argument needs to be true if the shape is closed.

But when I look at the function, with _shape_ you mean the `latlngs` parameter?
If so, when I look at the `closed` is interpreted, it actually closes (an action) the newly (based on the `latlngs`) created shape, so that the created shape is actually 'closed'.

So basically inside the function, a `close` action is performed on the shapedata to close it, creating a closed shape...

Therefore I suggest renaming the parameter from a 'noun' to a 'verb' as it gives a more clear understanding...

> Please revert the changes of replacing tabs with spaces.

Sorry about the spaces, used the wrong editor.
Thanks!
commit_messages: Rename 'closed' parameter of 'latLngsToCoords' to 'close' to avoid confusion (#8678)

body:
Bumps [bundlemon](https://github.com/LironEr/bundlemon) from 1.4.0 to 2.0.0.
Release notes

Sourced from bundlemon's releases.

bundlemon@2.0.0

No changes since bundlemon 2.0.0-rc.1 release notes

BREAKING CHANGES

  • Support node >= 14 https://github.com/LironEr/bundlemon/commit/eb140735ee3c76061384d04094d0b12807157ed4
  • Authentication changes (PR #103, #117)
    • Auto-create projects when using GitHub actions
    • The old way of using project ID without an API key will stop working in a few months so it's important to upgrade.
    • Creating GitHub output when not using GitHub actions now requires creating GitHub access token
  • Ignore fails on base branch (PR #139 ) resolves #126 Currently, it's without the option to change this behavior, in case someone needs it please open an issue and explain your use case.

Feature

  • Optional files option (PR #113)
  • Option to post GitHub output only on failures (PR #124) resolves #123
  • Add commit message to commit record and show it in the website reports chart (PR #127 #128 #129) resolves #116 set includeCommitMessage to true and set the commit message in CI_COMMIT_MESSAGE env var
  • Add option to approve limit exceeded (PR #133 #137) resolves #115
  • Ability to post GitHub output only on PR (PR #138)

Migration guide from v1 to v2

bundlemon@2.0.0-rc.1

BREAKING CHANGES

  • Ignore fails on base branch (PR #139 ) resolves #126 Currently, it's without the option to change this behavior, in case someone needs it please open an issue and explain your use case.

Features

  • Add commit message to commit record and show it in the website reports chart (PR #127 #128 #129) resolves #116 set includeCommitMessage to true and set the commit message in CI_COMMIT_MESSAGE env var

  • Add option to approve limit exceeded (PR #133 #137) resolves #115

  • Ability to post GitHub output only on PR (PR #138)

bundlemon 2.0.0-alpha.1 release notes

Migration guide from v1 to v2

bundlemon@2.0.0-alpha.1

This is the first alpha release of BundleMon v2, hopefully, there won't be any more breaking changes but keep in mind it might happen (:

BREAKING CHANGES

  • Support node >= 14 https://github.com/LironEr/bundlemon/commit/eb140735ee3c76061384d04094d0b12807157ed4
  • Authentication changes (PR #103, #117)
    • Auto-create projects when using GitHub actions
    • The old way of using project ID without an API key will stop working in a few months so it's important to upgrade.
    • Creating GitHub output when not using GitHub actions now requires creating GitHub access token

Feature

  • Optional files option (PR #113)

body:
Slava Ukraini, `leaflet` team!

This pull request resolves #8591, whereby `Tooltip`s were not added to the DOM while the map was moving.  

[@BasieP's analysis of the offending code](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/8591#issue-1411797195) was correct, as is the [workaround suggested](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/8591#issuecomment-1282942278);  However, [ I am using `react-leaflet`](https://github.com/PaulLeCam/react-leaflet/issues/1039), where this workaround is not an option.

An automatic test is included.
comments: @theGOTOguy could you stop adding new commits to this PR? It creates a lot of unnecessary noise. Besides, we will rebase and quash the commits either way.
Also please rebase your PR on `main` so we can merge if needed (no merge commits).

This is still an issue for me in production, and I'm wondering if you could take a look at the changes I've made and let me know if the solution as it sits is appropriate or if more changes are desired.
commit_messages:
Fix issue whereby tooltips loaded dynamically while moving the map were never shown. (#8672)

body:
Collapse several jobs to make the flow simpler and hopefully faster because of less job spinning-up / cache restoration & saving: 

- `setup` + `build` => `setup`
- `build-release` + `bundlemon` => `bundlemon`

With the previous approach, some jobs like `lint` could start earlier, but `npm run build` runs in just 6 seconds and `lint` isn't the bottleneck anyway, so it doesn't matter in practice.

Bumps [simple-git](https://github.com/steveukx/git-js/tree/HEAD/simple-git) from 3.14.1 to 3.15.0.
Release notes

Sourced from simple-git's releases.

simple-git@3.15.0

Minor Changes

body:
Removes the inheritance of the `filter` property on map tiles. This property was initially added in #451 as a fix for IE6-9, however since then this property has been standardized as an entirely different API. 

This has been causing issues (#8630), and the best course of action seems to be to simply remove this code entirely.

Since users might be relying on this implicitly, I have marked this a breaking. But perhaps I am being over presumptuous (do let me know).
comments:
> This property was initially added in https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/451

It seems this dates back to #90. Wow.

The default value for `filter` is `none`. Having `inherit` might apply filters from containing elements into the tiles, which seems undesired, so I'm OK with the change. I'm not aware Leaflet is applying filters to tile containers at all.
commit_messages: Stop inheriting `filter` CSS property on tiles (#8651)

body:
Corrected test to be able to get SVG size and coords correctly. Also discovered that a bug is still present with the help of https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/pull/8103#issuecomment-1235646390. 

When going through the debugger, `Draggable.disabled()` was being called if `zoomAnimation` is `false`. If `zoomAnimation` is `true`, `Draggable.enabled()` is called instead and is properly fixed.

This test will be slow due to the fact of `zoomAnimation` being enabled as the bug has not be fixed when `zoomAnimation` is `false`.

Fixes #8117.

Issue #7466 most likely will need to be reopened.

body:
After some try & error testing, I found out that the problem of #5895 and #6322 can be fixed with [img.decoding = 'async'](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLImageElement/decoding). The problem occurs only in Safari.

Before: [Editor](https://plnkr.co/edit/sSHewakwgyaYYOWq)
![safari-img-loading-fail](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19800037/199123507-95853b20-6a52-4f3b-9e2b-b86f8f710a49.gif)

Solution: [Editor](https://plnkr.co/edit/stU9bAzQV1DHFahp)
![safari-img-loading-working](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19800037/199123529-b26aa47d-618e-4bb6-80a5-041d4c6c8406.gif)

fixes #5895, fixes #6322
comments: @mourner can you please confirm with your mac
@Falke-Design both the before and after work in Safari v16.1 on my M1 Mac.

> both the before and after work in Safari v16.1 on my M1 Mac.

@mourner ok wow ... with LambdaTest it was possible to test with Safari 16 and it is no problem anymore. Should we still implement the fix for the other Safari versions?

> Should we still implement the fix for the other Safari versions?

I'd say no. If the latest version of Safari fixes this issue then it doesn't make sense to me to keep a quirk around, especially with 2.0 around the corner.

body:
This is a ~~blind (i.e. totally untested)~~ attempt to fix #8631.

I'm just using my code pattern for initializing synthetic events (from https://gitlab.com/IvanSanchez/gleo/-/blob/master/src/Platina.mjs#L1109 ) - instead of iterating through the properties of the existing event, this creates a init dictionary with the properties defined in the DOM specs.

This might not be the best solution, though. Perhaps the "DOM event cloning" functionality should be moved to `DomEvent.js`, and be called from the dblclick code.
comments:
Tests pass! Relying on `target.dispatchEvent(syntheticEvent)` seems to work just as expected.

~~The tests have failed on chrome+mac - but it's a `L.Popup` test, which should be unrelated to the `DoubleTap` code. Anybody with a mac can confirm?~~ I had to force a re-run of a couple of CI jobs.

body:
Hi,

I've made a custom plugin to declutter maps. It's like an alternative to the Marker cluster plugin. The way it works is that all markers has two states : a expanded state ("inflated") and a reduced state ("deflated") with another design, more compact and with less information to declutter the map. Here's a demonstration: https://meteo-concept.github.io/leaflet-inflatable-markers-group/example1.

It's possible to inflate/deflate a marker by right-clicking on it. The markers also adapt their state when the map is zoomed in and out to show as many markers as possible in their inflated state without overlap.

We've been using for several months on our sites (like https://www.meteo.bzh/climatologie/normales for instance) and we hope it can be useful to others.

Cheers,
commit_messages: Add Leaflet.inflatable-markers-group plugin (#8627)

body:
Added .leaflet-center css class.
Added 2 lines in Control.js _initControlPos creating 2 additional position options: topcenter & bottomcenter.
```
L.control.zoom({ position: 'topcenter'});
```
See https://solfisk.github.io/Leaflet.LayerGroup.Conditional/ for details.
commit_messages: Added leaflet.LayerGroup.Conditional to plugin list (#8614)

body:
Round off the fractional zoom level in order to use an integer value for requesting tiles. Such as `<baseurl>/3/2/4.png` instead of `<baseurl>/3.3/2/4.png` (notice the value `3` vs `3.3`).

This PR contains the same logical changes as #8580, but without the modifications from auto-formatting for easier review.

Closes https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/8276
comments: @mourner do you think this change can cause some problems? We would like to add it to the `v1` release

I removed `Math.round` in `GridLayer` and added it to `_clampZoom` in `TileLayer`. 

> There's gonna be an edge case when the GridLayer's minZoom or maxZoom are fractional as well - the tileZoom might fall outside of the clamp.

If this would be the case the user can overwrite the _clampZoom function in TileLayer

> Hmm, not familiar with the use cases, but that's a good catch. If there is a case where minNativeZoom is 2.2 and maxNativeZoom is 2.9, then the tileZoom will always be out of bound. I will wait for the team to decide on this one.

> As the examples are from tileLayer, and there could be plugins where people redraw differently at fractional zoom levels

For this reasons, I moved it to TileLayer

body:
Fixes #8222.

Implementation is pretty straightforward - replaces the old `resize` event handler on `Window`. It also feels nice to get rid of a 9-year-old hack.

As noted in #8222, this won't work in MSIE nor Edge < 79 - but we are not targeting those platforms anymore, so it should be fine.
comments: Maybe a good time to implement a test?
I'll try and squeeze a couple of test in the next couple of weeks.
@IvanSanchez @jonkoops I added some tests, after approval we can merge this PR
@Falke-design I still want to add a test chat changes the CSS properties of the map's container and checks for a `resize` event.
commit_messages:
Use ResizeObserver for map resizes (#8612)

Co-authored-by: Florian Bischof <design.falke@gmail.com>

body:
Splits off the update-triggering logic from L.Renderer into a new L.BlanketOverlay class. L.Renderer now only holds logic for keeping a list of L.Paths.

Intended for #8608.

This is a quick&dirty implementation without major testing. At first glance it doesn't seem to break anything. But there's pending stuff:

- [x] Should there be a hook point for the `animzoom` and `zoom` events? `L.Canvas`/`L.SVG` doesn't use it (since redraws only happen at `zoomend`/`viewreset`), but WebGL-based stuff will want to trigger a redraw.
- [x] Should there be a further abstraction of `reset`/`update` concepts? The current implementation has some "unconventional" event handlers and code paths to cover browser inconsistencies when it comes to `<canvas>` synchronization, and I don't want to break any of that.
- [x] Cleanup of event handlers? Subclasses (including `L.Renderer`) should be responsible for attaching event handlers to `zoomend`.
comments: I'm quite happy with the PR as it stands now. I've added a new example at `debug/vector/blanket.html` illustrating how a `<div>` `BlanketOverlay` updates.

> @IvanSanchez only to make sure, do this now cover all your usecases which are in #8608 described?

Yes, this covers the use cases nicely. Implementing a whole-map plugin should now be simpler, since the plugin only has one entry point (`_onSettled`). The position/sizeof the container is managed by `BlanketOverlay` in a consistent manner.

There are two *future* improvements:
- Make `L.Canvas` and `L.SVG` able to work with `continuous=true`. The code for the local origin of coordinates of `L.Path`s is convoluted, and is meant to work only at integer zoom levels AFAICS.
- Handle CSS-driven zoom animations. Trying to track them (by means of timers and `requestAnimFrame`) is a headache.

sadly I have no experience with that, so I can't really say if this is ok or not
No worries. Just need someone to verify the scripts work as expected.
Thanks @mourner!
commit_messages: Convert build scripts into ESM (#8610)

body:
Removes Android from the browser detection code and removes all related code based on these checks. This removes the following APIs:

- `L.Browser.android`
- `L.Browser.android23`
- `L.Browser.androidStock`
comments:
I think if we are going to keep any browser detection then it should be around our supported browsers. Or even better, the browser engine. For example, `L.Browser.chrome` could become `L.Browser.blink` and `L.Browser.firefox` could be `L.Browser.gecko`.

This is mostly because there is no real difference between browsers such as Chrome, Chromium, Opera, Samsung Internet, Edge, etc. They are all just shipping different versions of the same engine.
commit_messages: Remove Android from browser detection (#8607)

body: Removes Edge from the browser detection code, and removes all related code based on this. This removes the `L.Browser.edge` API.

body:
Bumps [nokogiri](https://github.com/sparklemotion/nokogiri) from 1.13.8 to 1.13.9.
Release notes

Sourced from nokogiri's releases.

1.13.9 / 2022-10-18

Security

  • [CRuby] Vendored libxml2 is updated to address CVE-2022-2309, CVE-2022-40304, and CVE-2022-40303. See GHSA-2qc6-mcvw-92cw for more information.
  • [CRuby] Vendored zlib is updated to address CVE-2022-37434. Nokogiri was not affected by this vulnerability, but this version of zlib was being flagged up by some vulnerability scanners, see #2626 for more information.

Dependencies

  • [CRuby] Vendored libxml2 is updated to v2.10.3 from v2.9.14.
  • [CRuby] Vendored libxslt is updated to v1.1.37 from v1.1.35.
  • [CRuby] Vendored zlib is updated from 1.2.12 to 1.2.13. (See LICENSE-DEPENDENCIES.md for details on which packages redistribute this library.)

Fixed

  • [CRuby] Nokogiri::XML::Namespace objects, when compacted, update their internal struct's reference to the Ruby object wrapper. Previously, with GC compaction enabled, a segmentation fault was possible after compaction was triggered. [#2658] (Thanks, @​eightbitraptor and @​peterzhu2118!)
  • [CRuby] Document#remove_namespaces! now defers freeing the underlying xmlNs struct until the Document is GCed. Previously, maintaining a reference to a Namespace object that was removed in this way could lead to a segfault. [#2658]

  • [CRuby] Vendored zlib is updated to address CVE-2022-37434. Nokogiri was not affected by this vulnerability, but this version of zlib was being flagged up by some vulnerability scanners, see #2626 for more information.

body: Removes Microsoft-specific Pointer Events from the browser detection code, and removes all related code based on this. This removes the `L.Browser.msPointer` API.
comments: This is good as a cleanup, but in the med-long term I'd love to go back to https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/7200 , and only provide support for `'pointer*'` events, dropping both `'touch*'` and `'mouse*'` events altogether.
@IvanSanchez Yes, agreed! I've pulled this into the milestone for 2.0. Perhaps we can get something done in this regard.
commit_messages: Remove Microsoft-specific Pointer Events from browser detection (#8603)

comments:
Looks good, but I had no good experiences with changing var to const / let automatically. I always had problems afterward. We have already a lot of tests, but I think it would be good to do some manual tests too. I can do some in the next days.

A last thing to consider: when we merge this, I think the most of PRs getting conflicts. Maybe we don't need to enable it now.
I agree with @Falke-Design , with the caveat that we're gonna break up all PRs sooner or later.

I think breaking existing PRs is fine. It's a small change for PR authors to resolve any conflicts.

As for testing this manually, if you want to take this on @Falke-Design feel free to do so. IMHO I think that any errors would likely already have been caught by CI.

I'd actually really prefer to merge this PR as soon as possible. With the other changes coming in it's going to be a hassle to keep rebasing it.

Also since we're not planning a 2.0 release any time soon we'd have plenty of time to test this change, even after merging.
I'm still not sure if we should do this now, but I will not be the one against it.
Anyone got objections against merging this in? If not I'd like to merge this in the next couple of hours.

body:
The function now checks that the parent contains this child before attempting to remove.
Fixes issue #8432. Please accept @Falke-Design

Fixes #8395.

@Falke-Design Please review. 
Please note - There was a explicit test for {-y} to be not set on infinite crs. This test *will fail*.

The test was added due to the issue https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/4338 - the problem was that TMS "needs an upper bound for the CRS's Y coordinate, to be able to flip the tile row". In the case of infinite crs, we don't have an upper bound, that's probably why they added the check on {-y}.
**In my PR, we don't use the upper bound, we simply set {-y} = (-1 * coords.y) - 1.** 
So, I think the test should be modified. 
Any suggestions ? @jonkoops @mourner  @IvanSanchez

body:
Round off the fractional zoom level in order to use an integer value for requesting tiles.

Closes #8276
comments: Maybe related to #3575

@Falke-Design I think there are two issues here.
1. `GridLayer` will load map tiles with decimal `z` value in url, like `<baseurl>/2.5/2/4.png`, leading to unsuccessful requests. (This PR tries to address this)
2. The map may have gaps showing up between tiles. (This is the issue discussed in #3575)

I think these two are separate issues and this PR tries to address the first one, or am I missing something?

Oh, it seems that I messed up the auto formatting during merge and caused quite a lot of line changes. If this is what I think as a separate issue, I can close this PR and open another PR for easier review.
Close PR in favour of #8613 for cleaner changes.

body:
modified TileLayer::getTileURL to support {-y} syntax from within infinite coordinate systems. 
The change is safe - the only new behavior is supporting {-y} in some cases which previously were unsupported. 

Fixes: #8395
comments: @Falke-Design  I need to add a test ?

For some reason there was a expliciet test for `{-y}` to be not set on infinite crs (this is also then one who is failing):

https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/blob/c33a57ca3a59c25f8874d09aec5fa2f1c6a98e5f/spec/suites/layer/tile/TileLayerSpec.js#L327-L345

Added with: #4338

@Falke-Design This is what I understood - 
In the issue #4338 , the problem was that TMS "**needs an upper bound for the CRS's Y coordinate, to be able to flip the tile row**". In the case of infinite crs, we don't have an upper bound, that's probably why they added the check on {-y}.
 In our case, **we don't use the upper bound**, we simply set **{-y} = (-1 * coords.y) - 1**. 
So, I think the test should be fixed. Do you have any suggestions for me regarding #8575 ?
@mourner @IvanSanchez maybe you can take a look into this. The tile and rendering logic is still pretty hard for me
@Falke-Design I reforked this repo. Should I open a new PR for this issue #8395 ?
@ShivangMishra go for it

body:
This Pull Request fixes an issue with the _animateZoom function.
The error seems to be happening because _map is undefined, it is recreational simply by creating a map + a marker on the map, then just zoom in & out a bunch whilst the marker is visible (atleast how I did it).

This is solved by simply checking if the map exists in these functions.

Images & videos of the error:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54480523/196010986-92f4494e-a585-46bf-ba9b-89d25682f95b.png)
**Video:**

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54480523/196011117-803344df-edbe-404e-930a-ea58d18294f6.mp4
comments: @Z3rio could you [rebase](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/topics/git/git_rebase.html) this PR on `main` and resolve the conflicts?

> @Z3rio could you [rebase](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/topics/git/git_rebase.html) this PR on `main` and resolve the conflicts?

There, this should now be Done.
Closing this because of no repsone and I'm not able to reproduce the error. If we get new information I will reopen this PR.

Hi all, i understand that this issue has been closed but the problem still persists using leaflet with Vue3 (Or a famework that proxy the map object). All the workarounds i can find are "just unwrap it", at it's not practical when you are developing something that is more complex than a map with 2 merkes on it. 

I can easily replicate this just by allowing leaflet to autoclose a popup generating the `Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading '_latLngToNewLayerPoint')` error.

Could this issue be re-opened ? Thanks!

@StefanoMantero please create a demo which throws the error, then I will reopen the issue and look into it.
The best would be to use www.leafletjs.com/edit.html but this is a vanilla js sandbox.

body:
closes #6397, perhaps

This is a intermediary PR that has several purposes:
  1. To gouge your interest for having those modifications (maybe going into 2.0 you already have a drown-out plan for how you'll go about tree-shaking and whatever else);
  2. To see if I'm going the right way with it;
  3. To spark a discussion on how you'd like to go about decoupling or if you have certain design pattern you'd like to go towards.
  4. To see if I'm actually capable of engaging this problem.

Am noob, pls no bully.
comments:
Generally I think this is the right thing to do — thanks for taking on this! Years ago I introduced this pattern because we wanted to make things modular (before ESM were a thing), and also avoid `Map` becoming too huge, but I think this is doing more harm than good — increasing complexity, introducing side effects to modules, etc. But I'll welcome more opinions.

Can you please rebase on `main`? Looks like some already landed PR changes are showing up in your diff. Also let's make sure this doesn't break the docs flow by generating them and reviewing the difference locally.
Damn, failed rebase again. I'll try again later :)
I always rebase by running `git pull http://github leaflet repo clone url`

@adrianaris I meant not commit the regenerated docs, just check the difference locally to see what's generated differently and investigate/fix appropriately. Currently committed docs show way too much difference so apparently something broke.

Yes, I understood what you meant, but I noticed the big difference and I didn't understand if it's normal.

I pushed it for you to see.

I'll try to figure it out but if you have some pointers for me now that would be nice.
Summoning @IvanSanchez for ideas 🙏

> Summoning @IvanSanchez for ideas

💨 *IvanSanchez appears in a puff of smoke* 💨

Personally I'm against this PR - the point of using ES modules (& treeshaking) is to reduce the amount of code being loaded, and `import`ing controls, svg and canvas renderers in the `Map` class immediately cancels that benefit.

In other words: there are use cases where a developer wants a Leaflet map displayed without any vector symbols (lines/circles/polygons), or without a `Canvas` renderer - and the approach proposed by this PR will *always* load the code for all controls, all handlers, and all renderers.

I don't feel like coupling/cohesion is a problem in the current architecture. Yes, the behaviour of controls/handlers is defined by options in the `Map`, but the alternative is to force the user to explicitly instantiate controls/handlers with the desired behavioural options and override the default.... and all of a sudden this becomes OpenLayers, and instantiating a tile layer requires the explicit instantiation of three different classes. (Which, granted, is not what this PR does, but it's what my brain is extrapolating)

Yes, ideally, this removes coupling between Leaflet's internal classes.... at the cost of increasing Leaflet's API surface (i.e. increasing coupling between leaflet's code and user's code).

(I'd even venture to say that the current form of this PR **increases** coupling - by having the controls/handlers/renderers use stuff from `Map` which is defined elsewhere)

I'm wondering if the ""right"" way to go is something akin to what I'm doing in my [not-so-secret-anymore WebGL map library](https://gitlab.com/IvanSanchez/gleo) - have a base `Map` class with no extraneous functionality, and then a façade `Map` class which loads a set of expected defaults - see https://gitlab.com/IvanSanchez/gleo/-/blob/master/src/MercatorMap.mjs

@adrianaris Yeah, kinda, but it's not exactly what I meant.

On one hand, "blank" classes with no functionality are my (currently) preferred way of dealing with circular dependencies. So yes on that.

On the other: There has to be a way to both:
- (a) Allow users having a `L.Map` with the default expected controls and handlers (zoom buttons, mouse drag, etc)
- (b) Allow users having a `L.Map` with no controls nor handlers (so they set up their own), loading code strictly on demand.

My point being that this PR doesn't allow for (b). Specifically, https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/pull/8549/files#diff-f7c61cee5bee8604986cfce68530ef8df7316a4e93ea6a2ddfb6e97fa4234421R12 makes things messy (and tree-shaking basically impossible)

(Sorry if I cannot provide a magical 100% correct answer - this is by no means an easy architectural problem to tackle)

Closing this as I feel like it actually has the same scope with what leaflet members are working towards with their major refactoring for the 2.0 (https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/discussions/8576#discussioncomment-3888966) + It's out of my depth and I believe that chances are slim for me to come up with a solution that you would accept. Cheers
Thanks for the efforts, starting a discussion like this is always appreciated.

body:
This test does depend on asynchronous behaviour as its loads 8 tiles onto the map, but those tiles are already in memory as a data URI and they load very quickly. With some brief `console.log` profiling, I observed all tiles loading within 2ms.

I thought about reducing the test's length by running assertions on the 8th `tileload` event, but that wouldn't guard against additional unnecessary tile load.

Instead, because the tiles load exceptionally quickly, I've wrapped the assertions in a 10ms debounce.

This speeds up the test from 251ms to 13ms

body:
Hello 👋🏼 

I had a user notice that when the map initally loads at a zoom level of `3`, the metric scale bar slightly cuts off the unit value of `km`. Please see screenshot below. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/85003930/194720547-6be93446-38bf-4a2c-bcbc-97326ed9b753.png)

Since this is a scale bar and the width of it cannot be changed, I think the only solution must be to reduce the font size of the text slightly so that this doesn't occur. 

It is an edge-case but noticeable enough that a user reported it. I have tested font size `10px` on many different zoom levels and it seems to fix this issue. 

I also searched for related issues to this and did not find any discussion on this previously. (Maybe it was decided not to be a big enough deal to fix?). Please let me know if I missed any background discussion on this issue.

Here is how it looks with the adjusted font size at the same zoom level:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/85003930/194720605-ec638e92-132a-4ec1-9580-91e84881f3ba.png)

Thanks
comments:
I don't think reducing the font size is the adequate answer - there's been a whole set of accessibility changes from 1.8 to 1.9, and this would go against.

If anything, there should be a `minWidth` option/value in `L.Control.Scale`, and just multiply the length and the measurement by a factor of 2 whenever the actual length is smaller.

Another option is to instead allow the text to overflow the `.leaflet-control-scale-line` container. I.e. remove/override:
https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/blob/3cb07e4577b9527a3453db1ee619fc7d5e730907/dist/leaflet.css#L439


Some other maps do it too:

![Screenshot_20221008-200838_Maps](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26493779/194747356-70b8bd0a-0d5f-4513-b389-d6a08070a82a.jpg)

The text could however overlap the scale itself, potentially utilizing a small text-shadow for contrast could help, e.g. `text-shadow: 0 1px #fff`.
Closing per https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/pull/8543#issuecomment-1272377313, feel free to continue the discussion.
Just chaning the size of the scale box will result in a not correct scale

body:
Fixes #8532

At certain coordinate and/or screen size combinations, `Map.setMaxBounds` ended up triggering an infinite `_panInsideMaxBounds` loop due to slight discrepancies in reprojected center points across loops.

We are supposed to break out of this loop if our recalculated centers are identical:

https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/blob/4372a9fcadce23d23a21370439179c09d1118ab3/src/map/Map.js#L503-L514

And our `_limitCenter` code was already set up to catch subpixel offsets, ignore them, and returning the identical center to break the loop.

Unfortunately it seems the projection instability can cause up to 1px offsets, which this code was not catching.

This PR adds a failing test for the problem as reported, using the `setView` values from the bug report. This test does appear to consistently fail.

The PR also updates `_limitCenter` to ignore up to 1 pixel offsets, which fixes the issue.

body:
Related to #8483

I was reviewing the PopUp keepInView test with the eye of speeding it up, however I found that the pan animation was forced on. This was introduced with #7792 to guard against infinite recursion from `(on moveend) -> _adjustPan -> panBy -> _resetView -> (fire moveend)`.

Reviewing the Popup code, we always expect `_adjustPan` to be triggered by its own `panBy` call but ordinarily the view will have updated and the `dx` and `dy` offsets will be 0, avoiding the recursive call. We only end up with the recursive call when `_resetView` is called, because the map doesn't have a chance to re-render itself (is that right?).

The fact that `_adjustPan` will always invoke itself allows an alternate solution: We can set a local variable when we start autopanning, and check it in the later invocation. If its present, we know the `moveend` currently being handled was invoked by the same function, and can thus return early – also avoiding the recursive invocation.

With this change, the associated test can be simplified and sped up from 812ms to 10ms (81x faster).

I'm raising this as a draft for now as I'm keen for thoughts on this as an alternate fix. I also want to do some manual testing varying pan distances and animations to further validate the change.
comments:
I'm happy opening this up as ready for review :)

I've added a debug page and had a play around with the keepInView popups. From my testing, I can confirm that the `_autopanning` local variable appears to be a reliable fix for the freeze issue that #7792 addressed.

As described in my comment earlier, I also noticed that there was no way to disable pan animations invoked by the keepInView logic. That meant my original attempt to speed up these tests was actually fragile and could break depending on future changes in `Map.panBy` even if the autopanning behaviour does not.

I have adjusted the test to work more reliably in that case, and added a new "short hop" to make sure we have coverage of `Map.panBy`'s animated pan and reset view behaviours.

After these changes, we're now seeing a speed up from 812ms to 271ms (3x faster).

The resulting tests now also have no dependence on the `_autopanning` alternate fix. If we think that change is too risky, we can drop it but still keep the faster tests :)

> Changing latlng with `keepInView: false`, doesn't move the map anymore

Oop, good catch! Thanks!

I've attached a quick fix for that by only setting the `_autopanning` flag when `keepInView` is set. :)
@Falke-Design could you give this PR another look?
commit_messages: Alternate fix for PopUp keepInView recursion and speed up associated test (#8520)

body:
Related to #8483 

Zoom animations are enabled by default within Leaflet, which adds a significant overhead to these numerous zoom-related tests.

I can see that Map.TouchZoomSpec chooses to disable animations on its tests for this reason:

https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/blob/579c90d27132c56ff2c6f7e2f6e4707c622e7676/spec/suites/map/handler/Map.TouchZoomSpec.js#L9

Applying that change here reduces the time to run these tests from 2693ms to 379ms, saving 2.3 seconds.

In making this change I have verified that `Map._tryAnimatedZoom` and `Map._onZoomTransitionEnd` is invoked by other tests. There doesn't appear to be an explicit test proving zoom-related animations however. I'm wondering if there's value expanding MapSpec's "#zoomIn and #zoomOut" tests to prove animations (a fixed 250ms cost, instead of 250 * N ms)?
commit_messages: Speed up tests Map.ScrollWheelZoomSpec and Map.DoubleClickZoomSpec (#8519)

body:
Related to #8483

The `panBy` calls within this test would invoke pan animations, adding 250ms per pan to the test's execution time. I assume these setTimeout calls were set at 300ms to wait for that animation to finish.

I don't believe this test needs to invoke animations. Disabling them and dropping the setTimeouts saves us half a second on the tests.
comments: Nice!

body:
This line of code will cancel a drag that starts during the zoom in/out animation. Said line looks extremely specific so there may well be a good reason it's there, but neither comments nor commit messages indicate a particular reason for its existence, and after removing it the tests continue to pass.

Please let me know if I've done something silly in this process. It's my first time doing a pull request ;)
comments: Maybe because of pinch zoom + drag on mobile

Looks like this goes way back to 10 years ago and fixes zooming during pan animation and panning during zoom animation: https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/commit/9625cdbbb96ab2e448d7444abde908b1fc10abdb

The current way it returns (based on `leaflet-zoom-anim` class) was introduced in https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/pull/3050

> **fixes** zooming during pan animation and panning during zoom animation

Currently in main, you can still zoom during panning. The problem in the issue this PR references is that if you **start** panning **during** a zoom, your "mousedown" input will be ignored and when you release, you'll instead click on the map. 

> Maybe because of pinch zoom + drag on mobile

Good point. I tested it and pinch zoom + drag works (to my eyes) exactly the same as before, probably because my fingers aren't robotic enough to pinch zoom without panning.

Feel free to compare the current version with this PR now hosted [here](https://lukasgimberis.com/leaflet).
Thank you for your contribution but this already fixed by #8415

body:
Ref #8483. Adds a Karma plugin that displays 10 slowest tests after running the test suite:

```
2833ms GridLayer number of 256px tiles loaded in synchronous animated grid @800x600px Loads 290, unloads 275 tiles on MAD-TRD flyTo()
2813ms TileLayer number of kittens loaded Loads 290, unloads 275 kittens on MAD-TRD flyTo()                                          
809ms  Popup L.Map#openPopup moves the map over a long distance to the popup if it is not in the view (keepInView)                   
665ms  Map.ScrollWheelZoom changes the option 'wheelPxPerZoomLevel'                                                                  
606ms  Path #events can add a layer while being inside a moveend handler                                                             
365ms  Map.ScrollWheelZoom changes the option 'wheelDebounceTime'                                                                    
321ms  LineUtil #polylineCenter computes center of a small line and test it on every zoom                                            
310ms  Map.ScrollWheelZoom scrollWheelZoom: 'center'                                                                                 
306ms  Map.ScrollWheelZoom zooms out while firing 'wheel' event                                                                      
300ms  Map.ScrollWheelZoom zooms in while firing 'wheel' event     
```

Also makes a few of the unit tests faster, cutting down overall time by ~10 seconds.
commit_messages: Add slow test stats and make some tests faster (#8486)

body:
Removes the `Util.bind()` function and replaces it with the standard [`Function.bind()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_objects/Function/bind) method. `Util.bind()` included backwards compatibility with older browsers, which is no longer required now that we have raised our target browsers.

This change is also needed to update the linter configuration as it introspects `.bind()` calls for certain rules (such as [`no-invalid-this`](https://eslint.org/docs/latest/rules/no-invalid-this)).
comments: Should we include `L.Util.bind` as an alias to `fn.bind` just to retain compatibility with some older code or plugins that may still use it?

@mourner Yeah, I wanted your input on this. We could leave a minimal implementation for it to retain backwards compatibility. Personally, I would like to get rid of large swaths of `Util` (and other components) and replace it with standard browser APIs, leaving a very minimal API exposed from Leaflet.
@mourner I'd like to go ahead and merge this in, do you have any objections?
commit_messages: Replace `Util.bind()` with `Function.bind()` (#8484)

body:
When running `npm test`:

- Silence `console.warn` output in the terminal which was annoying and unnecessary.
- Silence Rollup warnings (circular deps / export) because we don't care about those during tests.
comments: I don't know if this is so good. I think this one of the only ways for us to see if a (unwanted) warning is printed.

There's no way for us to determine if a warning is unwanted unless we test specifically for warning output in the tests. As for Rollup, it's reusing the config used for the builds and we can see the warnings when running the build script.

I also use the test to developing, so I can clearly say if a warning is expected or not. 
I personally have no problems if the warnings are visible but it's also ok for me if we hide them.
TBH I don't find the test output that verbose, and I'd prefer to see issues rather than to suppress that.

IDK maybe that's a sign of OCD in me, but I just find the output ... wrong. Like, not crafted in the way it was intended. Maybe I should try supressing each of the current logs manually in each test then...

body:
Closes #8458. Instead of relying on the local files being correct when generating integrity hashes, just fetch the published ones from `unpkg`. This makes this step way less fragile, and simplifies the process.

I also updated the algorithm to `sha256` (one of the options per the spec) because it's shorter and looks less intimidating in examples, and we don't care about super duper security here.
commit_messages: Improve integrity generation for releases (#8459)

body:
The problem was that the value of `fn` was overwritten and then passed again to `listens` in the propagation.

closes #8450
commit_messages: Fix Events.listens for nested propagations (#8457)

body: Also adds additional steps to the release process to prevent this from happening in the future.
comments:
> adds additional steps to the release process

are missing 😄

> are missing :smile: 

No longer :+1:
@mourner still seeing errors on https://leafletjs.com/, not sure why these resources do not match the hash.

@jonkoops I think I know — https://unpkg.com/leaflet@1.9.0/dist/leaflet.js has non-clean version in the header (should be just v1.9.0 but it also has a hash). Not sure why that happened, needs investigating. Meanwhile we can calculate the hashes for the files manually and update
I updated them manually, https://leafletjs.com/ is OK now.
commit_messages: Fix the resource integrity hashes (#8456)

body: Removes browsers we no longer want to support for v2 from the site.
comments:
I believe this would publish straight to the site after merging, which might not be something we want to have happen until we committed to version 2.

Do we want to keep from merging this in the mean time?

Good point, yes don't merge this.

@mourner the doc changes of #8196 already published too

> Do we want to mention Brave? Do we want to group Chrome & Edge under "blink engine browsers" or something like that?

Yeah, I was also not quite sure how to formulate this, naturally supporting Chromium-based browsers such as Brave and Samsung Internet would be fine considering they're all based on the same platform.

Yeah, this should be only merged when the latest released version has updated support table. Maybe let's convert into a draft to make sure it's not merged yet.

> @mourner the doc changes of #8196 already published too

If you're referring to IE6-8, I think that's fine. We don't really test anything on those browsers anymore, and even having them mentioned on the frontpage makes it sounds like this is an ancient library from ages ago 😅
Merged because docs are built from branch `v1`

body: I included an overview of the different types of versions that exist for Leaflet. This will allow the user to view the options quickly and easily. Also, I included an html overview section which outlines the html structure on how to incorporate Leaflet's hosted version within the header of the html file. I also included other aspects like the user's index.js and css. The goal is to show all together how the main setup should look like to allow the user to get a good base when first starting. Lastly, I referenced the quick start guide to direct the user just in case they have more intricate details about starting.
comments: I'm not a big fan of this change, it adds a lot of details to the page that don't necessarily make it easier to understand how to integrate Leaflet. Personally I am a fan of how this page looks now, which is nice and simple with links to more details when you actually need them.
@andresrivas20 thank you for your work but we decided that we will keep the page like it is now.

comments:
> @Belair34 Tests are failing

Weird, I could have sworn they were passing back then. Should be fixed now!

body:
I noticed that the quick start guide could use some an overview section that lists the topics that are going to be covered in that guide. This will add value to the open-source project because it will let the user know if the guide covers material that they are looking for or if they must go straight to the documentation.

I also added a quick links section that outlines the links that can take the user to the other parts of the project that include documentation. One link takes the reader to the documentation while the other takes the user straight to the tutorials. I think that how it was formatted before in a paragraph form was a bit inefficient since it made the user search for the links that were embedded in writing.

I also added a section specifically for the map tiles which focuses on detailing map tile services that can be incorporated with the API. In addition, I added a map tiling service called Maptiler which is very famous and easy to use. Lastly, I included a section that shows the format of how the URL is supposed to look like if one wanted to add their own map tiles. I believe that by having that template there is crucial to the quick start guide, instead of having it be a link.

Overall, these changes help summarize and outline the information better along with embedding links into the documentation.

body:
This PR adds explicit [permissions section](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/workflow-syntax-for-github-actions#permissions) to workflows. This is a security best practice because by default workflows run with [extended set of permissions](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/security-guides/automatic-token-authentication#permissions-for-the-github_token) (except from `on: pull_request` [from external forks](https://securitylab.github.com/research/github-actions-preventing-pwn-requests/)). By specifying any permission explicitly all others are set to none. By using the principle of least privilege the damage a compromised workflow can do (because of an [injection](https://securitylab.github.com/research/github-actions-untrusted-input/) or compromised third party tool or action) is restricted.
It is recommended to have [most strict permissions on the top level](https://github.com/ossf/scorecard/blob/main/docs/checks.md#token-permissions) and grant write permissions on [job level](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-jobs/assigning-permissions-to-jobs) case by case.
comments: This makes sense to me, thanks @sashashura!
commit_messages: GitHub Workflows security hardening (#8419)

Release notes

Sourced from uglify-js's releases.

v3.17.0

Features

  • merge common tail of if statements (996836b67e1800af188d7ca4e79813967ebc8bc2)
  • eliminate superfluous Object() wrappers (db6fd6db3e8eaa0b2ebbddb5e1cbcea81f0631ab)
  • improve elimination of return statements (08c386f363c8e3549e63c2d996c0e4f11c4cf116, ab5c7e6863f0a898798cf3b2fd87a52a89ed018d, 6667440aafa04669e99c641ef945d6903e086b7a, e39f33e41b1234b195b90d299014f40a999a8608, 64e3ceec3b6a7ee37dc4772dc3ad88542013f88f, 8076d66ae58315671821d9ecaa1f726f509e331d, 884842cd6ceb49766c152a60b151fcf386c13831, a9d9af53e9f469ed89f0be0a53da2a0ac07f3733)
  • improve compression of ternary expressions (672cdfa57ae67aae726f5b46ea20638aa1e9ce1d)
  • exclude latest ECMAScript runtime properties from builtin mangling (8a07f1202c135bd2fa6f2d5cc0231c466e73242e)
  • introduce --expression for ease of handling bookmarklets or JSON expressions (f451a7ad79165dda0d3f7fa7a56b3841eeba8174)
  • improve resolution and accuracy of source-maps (2c3c4ec32381bad3f21bf2778470d58abba7b82a)
  • inline function calls with simple assignments (5a4cd09938e46bbf7d9a875e03ce7e99c6e6c442)

Bumps [uglify-js](https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS) from 3.16.2 to 3.16.3.
Release notes

Sourced from uglify-js's releases.

v3.16.3

Features

  • improve elimination of return statements (0207b46d70caeecf332572ed69c0791bcfd733ae, c8d98f4787f402c283cb1b3a31d7ce325d209281)
  • merge common tail of if statements (d89f0965aac64aa6b3a08c10950ae8eba486b29e, 3dcf098468e08e9809079e1d9b5c68ac7e2ea980, 902292f776d4223e3b603729813e201328dd1b49, b92a89f32573e5dea946957b307769202099f8de)
  • improve compression of non-trivial function parameters (154edf0427d2a871a73ffd905537d5286346244f, 24443b676401005724defe2a4339944127656972, b371dc2d1ed523e9a8b38ef4eb5826fa0fdfcf05)
  • support import & export of non-ECMAScript identifiers (d67daa8314c9ce9ab9df6fd810f2cd0a2909c1ed)

  • assignment operator (5792f301757770b5314ec8d3df803fd6458d1669, f0120e90b6eae20e46eb38e815654f16d8a5d896)
  • default parameter (ec4558be29d5381ed10f0b5aecfcf8273da00aaa)

  • import statement (b2bc2e1173152c48096c032eb16921bfcbfae33e)
  • rest parameter (38bd4f65d06fb0556fdb6af46af0d40de79008c5)
  • spread syntax (56e9454f1f29097d41a422bbe7cc88f4cdafb29f)

body:
Hard to test without running the action, but should do https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/8349#issuecomment-1190756122

But I tested running commands myself and uploaded to https://davetapley.com/assets/leaflet.tar,
which can be used in a `package.json` as:
```json
 "dependencies": {
  "leaflet": "https://davetapley.com/assets/leaflet.tar",
```

Assuming if this works it'll push to https://leafletjs-cdn.s3.amazonaws.com/content/leaflet/main/leaflet.tar
as existing https://leafletjs-cdn.s3.amazonaws.com/content/leaflet/main/leaflet.zip does.
comments: I'm holding off on merging this in for now as I think we can actually start thinking about removing the compilation step from Leaflet entirely.

body:
Introduces a `module` entrypoint to the package to allow some tooling to load the ECMAScript module variant of Leaflet. The goal of this PR is to introduce this as a non-breaking change, preserving the Leaflet global `L` to avoid breaking existing code.

This PR is limited in scope an purposefully and does not try to implement the following:

**[Tree-shaking](https://webpack.js.org/guides/tree-shaking/)**
This requires us to further decouple internals of Leaflet, ensuring that objects are not grouped together (e.g. `Control.Zoom`). Fully supporting this will also mean that we have to mark the [side effects](https://webpack.js.org/guides/tree-shaking/#mark-the-file-as-side-effect-free) of the package.

**[Conditional exports](https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#conditional-exports)**
This is a new feature in Node.js that allows us to specify specific ESM and CommonJS entrypoints. It also prevents internals of the package from being exposed unintentionally since the exported API surface is defined explicitly.

This feature is not widely supported by tooling at this time, but will be preferred in the future as Node.js has never officialy supported the `module` field (unlike many bundlers). Since we currently do not offer running Leaflet under Node.js this is not a priority. 

As more tooling (such as bundlers) move to this standard we will likely end up implementing this.

Closes #7055
comments:
I've added a debug HTML that loads the ESM version directly into the browser without the need to add a bundler. And it seems that this is working as expected!

![Screenshot showing Leaflet working in ESM mode](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/695720/177526556-1bf7f9f5-7570-4359-9eeb-a56c75dae9cf.png)
Is it possible to add a test?
@Falke-Design it's hard to say without knowing where `../libs/leaflet` resolves to.
../libs/leaflet is the new generated file of your PR
@Falke-Design do you have a reproducible example somewhere I can use?
I will create one tomorrow

So I have been looking around to see if we can test this functionality but I think that is tad hard to accomplish. The reason for this is that we are [using a Karma plugin](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/blob/be871e6f706bc0567a211f873225077f4cf05b99/spec/karma.conf.js#L38) to compile the source with Rollup. The configuration it uses is separate from all the existing Rollup configuration for the build.

This also means that we are not really end-to-end testing our package from the perceptive of the consumer. This is also true for the UMD module we are distributing now.
@jonkoops here is the example, it is builded with webpack: https://github.com/Falke-Design/leaflet-esm-test

I've added some changes so that a default export is present which is the exact same as the global `L`. This will make it less likely that folks will run into any issues when upgrading. This allows the following:

```js
import * as L from 'leaflet';
```
To be turned into:
```js
import L from 'leafet';
```
And still allows named imports to co-exist:
```js
import L, { Map } from 'leafet';
```
It also ensures that the global `L` and the default imported `L` are equivalent, making it less error prone for plugins:
```js
import L from 'leaflet';
import '@geoman-io/leaflet-geoman-free';

L === window.L; // true
L.PM === window.L.PM; // true
```

@Falke-Design I've done some testing on your example code and managed to get things working properly with the latest changes on this PR. I've opened up a PR on your repo where you can see the code I used to test (https://github.com/Falke-Design/leaflet-esm-test/pull/1).

Make sure to build Leaflet locally on this PR and then [`npm link`](https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/v8/commands/npm-link) it into your example code and it should function as expected.

@Falke-Design @IvanSanchez @mourner can I ask y'all to take another look at this PR? As far as I am concerned we can go ahead with this and start rolling out betas for 1.9 (are we tracking this anywhere?).
@jonkoops thank you. I will take a look at it in the evening.

body:
Fixes: #8300

Will add test and comments if maintainers support this direction. Another option is to change `pruneTiles` so that it uses `this._tileZoom` instead of pulling the zoom off the map directly. This would leave the layer rendering until Math.round(this._map.getZoom()) > maxZoom` or in the example in the attached issue 3.5.

body:
We compared different Browsers (https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/7403#issuecomment-1101669097) and it shows us that all other Browsers than OSX(Mac), Safari, and Chrome on Linux have a double deltaX value. So we need for this Browsers `2 * devicePixelRatio`.

Fix: #7403, Close #7477.

We need to check if every Browser works fine:

- [x] **Win 10**
  - [x] Firefox (@Falke-Design, @KommX, @jinchun-wang)
  - [x] Chrome (@Falke-Design, @jinchun-wang)
  - [x] Edge (@Falke-Design, @jinchun-wang)
- [x] **Win 11**
  - [x] Firefox (@jinchun-wang)
  - [x] Chrome (@jinchun-wang)
  - [x] Edge (@jinchun-wang)
- [x] **Linux**
  - [x] Firefox (@zdila, @paulatthehug)
  - [x] Chrome (@paulatthehug)
  - [x] Edge (@IvanSanchez)
- [x] **OSX**
  - [x] Firefox (@jeffreykog)
  - [x] Chrome (@jeffreykog)
  - [x] Edge (@jeffreykog)
  - [x] Safari (@paulatthehug, @jeffreykog)

Demo: 
v1: https://plnkr.co/edit/gqQUNU9mf6RiqxD4
v2 (incl. macOS): https://plnkr.co/edit/vtEzxb7P0EFCkHoq
comments:
Hello,

I've tested 
Windows 10 version 21H2 (OS Build 19044.1766)
Windows 11 version 21H2 (OS Build 22000.739)
Windows Server 2022 version 21H2 (OS Build 22348.768)
Firefox 101.0.1 (64-bit)
Chrome 102.0.5005.115 (64 bits)

The absolut delta is 1 but the direction of zoom in / out seems inverse.
Please have a check again.
The same result of my test on Edge on Win10, 11, server 2022, the absolute delta is 1, the direction is inverse.
Sorry you did 'zoomBefore - map.getZoom()' so it is ok now for all. Excellent!!
It looks like there is a problem on Firefox on Mac, I need to investigate more
Why did not 'Map options - zoomDelta' apply to the change of the mouse wheel? And however it's working when pressing + or - on the keyboard

> Why did not 'Map options - zoomDelta' apply to the change of the mouse wheel? And however it's working when pressing + or - on the keyboard

@jinchun-wang [zoomDelta](https://leafletjs.com/reference.html#map-zoomdelta) is not applied to the mousewheel zooming.
> Controls how much the map's zoom level will change after a [zoomIn()](https://leafletjs.com/reference.html#map-zoomin), [zoomOut()](https://leafletjs.com/reference.html#map-zoomout), pressing + or - on the keyboard, or using the [zoom controls](https://leafletjs.com/reference.html#control-zoom). Values smaller than 1 (e.g. 0.5) allow for greater granularity.

If you want to change the zoomDelta while scrolling you need to play around with [wheelPxPerZoomLevel](https://leafletjs.com/reference.html#map-wheelpxperzoomlevel)
But wheelPxPerZoomLevel depends on device, os and browser.
Is it possible to add a new option 'maxZoomDelta' to apply on mouse wheel action? By default it can be no limit. In our cases we don't need fast zoom in/zoom out by mouse wheel.

Hi!

I tested this on OSX (M1 Max), on the built-in high-dpi monitor, an external high-dpi monitor, and an external 1080p monitor.

- Chrome 103.0.5060.134: Working
- Firefox 103.0.1: Working
- Safari 15.6 (17613.3.9.1.5): Working
- Edge 103.0.1264.77: Working

Zoom delta used in every browser is 1, as it should. So this is a go for OSX.
@jeffreykog very nice thank you!
@IvanSanchez do you have Edge on Linux? I know the chance is very low 😄

> @IvanSanchez do you have Edge on Linux?

I do, but I feel dirty about it.

I just tried out the v2 plunkr. Zoom delta is +/-1. I do not have a high-dpi monitor for this, but I tested both at 100% and 200% in-browser scaling (the `Ctrl`+`+` thing). I'm checking off the linux+edge box.

Explicitly setting `border: 0` to the dialog's iframe to override this.

Release notes

Sourced from eslint's releases.

v8.17.0

Features

  • 55319e1 feat: fix indent bug with semicolon-first style (#15951) (Milos Djermanovic)
  • f6d7920 feat: add allowNamedExports option to no-use-before-define (#15953) (Milos Djermanovic)

Bug Fixes

  • 54c0953 fix: cleanup typos (#15939) (Nick Schonning)
  • 845a7af fix: typo ocatal -> octal (#15940) (Nick Schonning)

Documentation

  • b915018 docs: Update website UI to latest (#15944) (Nicholas C. Zakas)
  • f0bb609 docs: Update Exponentiation operator MDN link (#15960) (Pranjal Jain)
  • baa0153 docs: Use correct past tense "left" instead of "leaved" (#15950) (Frederik Braun)
  • 1351a9b docs: Add Resources section to rule pages (#15901) (Nicholas C. Zakas)
  • 68cf0fb docs: cleanup typos (#15936) (Nick Schonning)
  • 13b62ae docs: use-dart-sass instead of node-sass (#15912) (Deepshika S)
  • c81c5d6 docs: add social media links (#15920) (Deepshika S)
  • 0d6a50b docs: fix openjs link (#15917) (Amaresh S M)

body:
Bumps [rollup](https://github.com/rollup/rollup) from 2.73.0 to 2.74.1.
Release notes

Sourced from rollup's releases.

v2.74.1

2022-05-19

Bug Fixes

  • Revert #4498 until some issues are understood and resolved

v2.74.0

2022-05-19

Features

  • Remove unneeded default values for function parameters (#4498)

Bug Fixes

  • Use a consistent mechanism to resolve the config file to avoid issues on Windows (#4501)
  • Avoid an inaccurate warning about an event emitter leak for complicated builds (#4502)
  • Ensure that reexporting values from other chunks via dynamic imports does not reference non-imported variables (#4499)

Pull Requests

  • #4498: Tree shake parameter defaults (@​lukastaegert)
  • #4499: Ensure reexports are available for namespaces (@​lukastaegert)

body: That may be a harsh move without prior discussion. But I give it a try.
comments:
We are currently in the process of stabilizing Leaflet 1.8 and eventually working our way up to version 2.0 which will drop support for older browsers.

Most likely our minimum support target for version 2.0 will be ES2015, at which point we'd  want to refactor all of our code (including documentation).

I am closing this PR now as it does not fit into the current timeline and will likely end up out of sync over time. When the time comes that we move to a newer syntax in general help would be appreciated.
Sounds like a good way to proceed 🙂 Thanks!

body:
I've come across a situation where I need to react to `layeradd` in the `LayerGroup`.

The previous attempt at #1122 failed because there was no `fire` method in `LayerGroup`.
Things have changed since then, and `LayerGroup` now inherits this method from `Evented`.

I've verified that the example from [this comment](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/pull/1122#issuecomment-10155929) works.

- Fixes #7822 - Fixes #4179 This is my initial attempt that is working. It should also play nice with #8250, but additional testing is needed. **Changes include**: - Vectors rendered in SVG have a `tabindex` to be focusable by keyboard - Vectors rendered in Canvas have [Canvas sub DOM](https://www.tpgi.com/html5-canvas-sub-dom/) `div` elements for each. These elements have their [`role` set to `graphics-symbol`](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/pull/8251#discussion_r876430498) (same as the implicit role for SVG ``), and `tabindex` making them focusable by a keyboard. When they're focused, `redraw` is called, and the tied canvas element is outlined. They translate `keypress` event to the associated vector layer leaflet object. - `Path` class has new option `keyboard` with default `true` similar to `Marker` - `Path` class has new option `title` (used as `` in SVG, and `title` attribute in Canvas sub DOM), with defaults set for every subclass of a `Path` - `Path` class has new option `desc` to provide alternative text description of a drawn feature (used as `<desc>` in SVG, and `aria-describedby` in Canvas sub DOM). - New page in the debug that renders the same simple map with both SVG and Canvas (see on the demo) <details><summary><b>Demo</b></summary><br> <img src="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/982323/169356718-bf568754-0947-4045-96be-b655f5ce8e8d.gif" /> </details> --- **Possible discussion** I tied canvas sub DOM elements to `layer._path`. `layer._path` is already used in SVG to store the actual path element and is returned by Path's `getElement.` On one hand., using `_path` is confusing. Still, it allows us to utilize changes for popup interaction that rely on `getElement` in #8250. I'll be happy to hear different opinions on the matter.
comments: @alekzvik I have updated the initial PR description of the changes to reflect some of the latest changes and also avoid the term "shadow".

> @alekzvik I have updated the initial PR description of the changes to reflect some of the latest changes and also avoid the term "shadow".

Thank you, I have also updated the demo gif to reflect changes after adding the title/description.

> ****Areas of improvement****
> 
> - Popups do not open with keyboard in Canvas but work in SVG

The work on this PR is phenomenal and I highly appreciate it, however keyboard operability is quite important, do you think it should be implemented separately?

> The work on this PR is phenomenal and I highly appreciate it, however keyboard operability is quite important, do you think it should be implemented separately?

I was going to suggest moving it into a separate PR, but I figured out how to do it, so it's no longer a problem.

For reviewers to test this out locally:

1. Go to `debug/vector/simple-canvas-svg.html`
2. [Start a screen reader](https://leafletjs.com/examples/accessibility/#test-your-maps) (if things get too noisy use <kbd>ctrl</kbd> to temporarily pause speech)
3. <kbd>tab</kbd> to vectors and press <kbd>enter</kbd>

Keep in mind https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/pull/8251#pullrequestreview-985965212:

> While there may be some imperfections (pointed out below), this PR does enable vector accessibility!

Hi @alekzvik,

> Vectors rendered in SVG have a tabindex to be focusable by keyboard

Are these vectors always supposed to be interactive, for example, to display a popup or tooltip, or as a form field to adjust a value?

`tabindex="0"` is ONLY for interactive elements that need to be focusable using Tab and Shift + Tab, for example, buttons, links, form fields. (`tabindex` is sometimes mis-understood and mis-used on the wrong elements.)

If the Vector needs to be available to assistive technology like screen readers, maybe it should be identified as an image?

Here is a basic example:

```svg
<svg aria-labelledby="myTitleId myDescId">
  <title id="myTitleId">A descriptive name</title>
  <desc id="myDescId">Optionally, a longer description ...</desc>
  ...
</svg>
```

Does that help?

Nick

> > Vectors rendered in SVG have a tabindex to be focusable by keyboard
> 
> Are these vectors always supposed to be interactive, for example, to display a popup or tooltip, or as a form field to adjust a value?
> 
> `tabindex="0"` is ONLY for interactive elements that need to be focusable

(Thanks for your feedback @nfreear, across multiple issues and PRs, highly appreciated!)

No these vectors are not always supposed to be interactive. The distinction between interactive and non-interactive vectors (similar to for markers: https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/issues/8116) could be addressed separately, IMO.

body:
- Fixes #8116 - Fixes #7527 **Changes include:** - Marker has default `role` of `img` as a non-interactive element. - When Popup is bound, it sets the `role` of the element to `button` - When Popup is bound, it reflects its state (open/close) in the `aria-expanded` attribute of the bound element (as true/false) **Demo**
Demo
**Discussion points** Both issues mentioned discuss Marker/Popup interaction specifically, but changes made here are on the layer level. This part is controversial since I am not sure if this is the responsibility of a Popup or a Marker. I am open to discussion and feedback here. The main problem I see here is that the behavior will work for some Layers and not others. **Alternative** The alternative implementation I see is to move this code to Marker and add Popup events for bind/unbind marker can react to. This way, the behavior will work only for Marker/Popup interaction and be more explicit. Please let me know what you think in the comments.
comments:
> changes made here are on the layer level. This part is controversial since I am not sure if this is the responsibility of a Popup or a Marker. I am open to discussion and feedback here. The main problem I see here is that the behavior will work for some Layers and not others.

Is that the reason why these changes don't affect markers in e.g. `debug/map/map.html`?

> Is that the reason why these changes don't affect markers in e.g. `debug/map/map.html`?

Thanks for spotting. This example does not work because of `LayerGroup` usage. Since I am manipulating underlying DOM objects, I will need to add code to call `getElement` for each layer of the LayerGroup, similar to what I did [here](https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/blob/main/src/layer/Tooltip.js#L361-L365)

There are 2 issues here regarding `divIcon`s. I retracted an earlier review comment, in an attempt to clarify, let's break it down: 1. If we use the suggested `role="img"` (https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet/pull/8250/commits/77dd2e95ccc0f4cb9db16aff530768621398d3cf), note that: - [`img` is not named from (child) content](https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-1.1/#namefromcontent) in [custom HTML](https://leafletjs.com/reference.html#divicon-html):
versus `div` without `role="img"`: - (and also, `role="img"` is redundant for `` element markers) 2. If we use `role="button"` (and `aria-expanded`): Can cause invalid HTML, e.g. if custom HTML is used to insert a `

> * `role="img"`:

Yes, seems like `role` `img` is redundant.

> * `role="button"` (and `aria-expanded`):
> Can cause invalid HTML, e.g. if custom HTML is used to insert a `<button>` or `<a href>` inside (now) `role="button"`

The mitigation strategy that comes to mind is to make an option to disable `role` and `aria-expanded` modifications.

> * `divIcon` is named that way because it uses a `div`, but it is technically not just a `div` if we change the semantics using `role`.

But if we add handlers for `click` and `keypress` to open a popup, that makes it a button, and the button role is used here to clarify this interaction possibility to the screen reader.

body:
This PR addresses #8111 & #8112. I've used the approach described in mentioned issues. I had to add logic for checking if the layer we're working with is a single `Layer` (one Marker, Polygon, etc.) or a `LayerGroup` (e.g., a group of Markers). Changes include: 1. The layer a tooltip is bound to now has an `aria-describedby` attribute 2. Every tooltip has an id to accommodate the change above 3. Tooltips are open when acquiring focus and close on blur Here is a before/after demo on a `debug/map/tooltip.html` with Voice Over narration visible:
Before
After
comments: Will need others to review the logic, but this looks really good IMO, @alekzvik!

Hi all. Is there a way to prevent this behaviour?

I have CircleMarkers of which the color changes when clicked on (using the setStyle function). But now they are getting the black and white outlines?
@MartijnHarmenzon if this change is causing problems for you could you create a new issue with a reproducible case? This makes things easier to keep track of for us.

Hey @Malvoz,

We have just encountered a similar issue as @MartijnHarmenzon .

We obviously get the accessibility requirements (and it's actually super nice with a keyboard), but it's causing visual boxes on Google Chrome (not Firefox) by using our mouse and no keyboards, which make things look buggy (we get the "box outline" on a click on a polygon without touching the keyboard from my point of view this is UX/UI bug, especially since we handle the highlighting more nicely on our side).
I'll try to build a reproducible example in the coming days.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20242665/201950036-e9b22708-7549-48d6-b203-4e09a31ea264.png)
@FloChehab Please create a new issue for discussion.
Yes, I'll do that in the coming days.

> @MartijnHarmenzon if this change is causing problems for you could you create a new issue with a reproducible case? This makes things easier to keep track of for us.

I have created an example:
https://codepen.io/martijnharmenzon-the-looper/pen/eYKPazW

The left circle (green) on the map has no tooltip an looks the way I want it to look when clicked on/ selected.
The right circle (red) on the map does have a toolipt and looks 'wrong' (in my opinion) when clicked on/ selected.

2022-05-13

Features

  • Do not treat Object.defineProperty/ies as side effect when called on an unused object (#4493)
  • Do not assume that assigning a property can create a getter with side effects (#4493)

body:
Hello, this is my first PR to Leaflet

fix for issue #6551 

Modified the Popup class's Layer to include a keydown eventListener to close the popup upon esc keydown
comments:
@joeyskuo This needs to be tested in several browsers and platform. In how many different platforms have you tested this?

I'm not entirely sure this will fix all the issues from #6551 - are popups focusable elements capable of receiving `keydown` events reliably?

> @joeyskuo This needs to be tested in several browsers and platform. In how many different platforms have you tested this?
> 

Hi Ivan, thank you for the review; I have tested this change in the following configurations:

**Dev Environment**
Leaflet version: 1.8.0
Browser (with version): Chrome 101.0.4951.54 (Official Build) (x86_64)
OS/Platform (with version): macOS Mojave 10.14.5

**Test Environment**
Viewing (https://plnkr.co/edit/4hXgn7EMinn9Wwn6)
Viewing (https://plnkr.co/edit/pkOzSCsI5QvtAcAe)

Leaflet version: 1.8.0
Browsers (with version): Safari 12.1.1
OS/Platform (with version): macOS Mojave 10.14.5

**Using Safari UserAgent**
Viewing (https://plnkr.co/edit/4hXgn7EMinn9Wwn6)

Leaflet version: 1.8.0
Browsers: Microsoft Edge
IE 11
IE 10
Firefox - Mac
Firefox - Windows
Chrome - Windows

> I'm not entirely sure this will fix all the issues from #6551 - are popups focusable elements capable of receiving `keydown` events reliably?

The popups aren't focused/focusable from what I've worked with so far. The keydown events are triggered when the marker is focused. Referencing the original poster,

**Steps to reproduce**
Add a marker to a map
Bind a popup to that marker
Click the marker to open the popup
Try to close the opened popup by pressing Esc

**Expected behavior**
The opened popup should be closed when the Esc-Key is pressed

**Current behavior**
The popup get's only closed when the layer the popup is bound to is not focusable

> I'm not entirely sure this will fix all the issues from #6551

I've noticed that in the test case (https://plnkr.co/edit/4hXgn7EMinn9Wwn6), if a popup is opened and you tab through until you focus on a child element of the popup (either the hyperlink or the close button), the esc button does not close the popup. I think that closely relates to this issue but I can agree that this commit does not address that

> The popups aren't focused/focusable from what I've worked with so far. The keydown events are triggered when the marker is focused. 

Ah, I misunderstood your approach. In that case, I suggest moving the functionality to the already existing `_onKeyPress` method, the one that checks against keycode 13 ("Enter" key).

I'm slightly concerned that this might fail for popups on non-interactive layers (since they're not focusable). But since this shouldn't have any negative side effects, this addition should be fine.

> In that case, I suggest moving the functionality to the already existing `_onKeyPress` method, the one that checks against keycode 13 ("Enter" key).

I initially added the functionality to the '_onKeyPress' method, but it didn't end up working due to the onKeyPress event not being fired for all keys (e.g. ALT, CTRL, SHIFT, ESC) in all browsers. After rediscovering that I added it to the onKeyDown event

> 
> I'm slightly concerned that this might fail for popups on non-interactive layers (since they're not focusable). But since this shouldn't have any negative side effects, this addition should be fine.

It may not affect non-interactive layers due to focus as you said, however I believe in that case the map keyboard handler would be active

body:
Fixes #8225.

When clicking on a `<label>` linked to an `<input>` (or vice versa), browsers trigger an extra click on the related element, as per https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/forms.html#the-label-element . This causes the `DomEvent.DoubleTap.js` logic to activate, and fire a ghost `dblclick` event.

So after sleeping on the problem, I found what should be a reliable approach: if the problem is the extra clicks that browsers introduce on `<label>`s... ignore those! Get the propagation path of the event, and check if:
- The event happened on a `<label>`, or on a child of a `<label>`
- The `<label>` has a `for` attribute (thus ignoring standalone labels and nested labels)
- The event is not happening on an `<input>` or child of an `<input>` (which means a nested label)

I think this approach is sound, but I haven't tested it extensively (or, to be honest, at all). I'm assuming that browsers do *not* trigger an extra click when the `<input>` is nested within a `<label>`, but I might be wrong about that.

Do note that `composedPath` is not implemented by all browsers (hence the `if (e.composedPath)` branch), so... (*checks notes*)... IE, Edge<74 and Safari<=9 would still display the buggy behaviour of #8225.

cc @pgrondelaers
comments: Can we use `Event.path` instead of `composedPath`? Also see: #8226

> @IvanSanchez I added also an test, please take a look on it before merging

That test fails on the `main` branch and passes on the `label-dblclick` branch (in my Firefox 100.0). It's perfect.
commit_messages:
DomEvent.DoubleTap ignores clicks on <label>s (#8227)

* DomEvent.DoubleTap ignores clicks on <label>s

Fixes #8225.

When clicking on a <label> linked to an <input> (or vice
versa), browsers trigger an extra click on the related
element. This causes the DoubleTap logic to activate
and fire a ghost dblclick event.

This change makes the DoubleTap logic ignore clicks on
labels or children of labels (but not when there's
an <input> on the propagation path of the event, which
means there's an <input> nested inside a <label>).

* typo: label 'ref'→'for' attribute

* Added DomEvent.getPropagationPath() polyfill

* Add test

Co-authored-by: Florian Bischof <design.falke@gmail.com>
